parts:
```main.tex
\begin{abstract}
A general method to determine covariant Lyapunov vectors in both discrete-
and continuous-time dynamical systems is introduced. This allows to address 
fundamental questions such as the degree of hyperbolicity, 
which can be quantified in terms of the transversality of these intrinsic vectors.
For spatially extended systems, 
the covariant Lyapunov vectors have localization properties 
and spatial Fourier spectra qualitatively different
from those composing the orthonormalized basis obtained in the standard procedure
used to calculate the Lyapunov exponents.
\end{abstract}

\pacs{05.70.Ln,87.18.Ed,45.70.-n}
\maketitle

Measuring Lyapunov exponents (LEs) is a central issue in the investigation
of chaotic dynamical systems because they are intrinsic observables that
allow to quantify a number of different physical properties such as sensitivity
to initial conditions, local entropy production and attractor
dimension \cite{review}. Moreover, in the context of spatiotemporal chaos, the
very existence of a well-defined Lyapunov spectrum in the thermodynamic limit
is a proof of the extensivity of chaos \cite{ext_chaos}, 
and it has been speculated that the small exponents 
contain information on the ``hydrodynamic'' modes of the dynamics 
(e.g., see \cite{ecpo} and references therein).

In this latter perspective, a growing interest has been devoted not only to the
LEs but also to some corresponding vectors, with the motivation
that they could contribute to identifying both the real-space structure of 
collective modes \cite{Demonte} and the regions characterized by stronger/weaker
instabilities \cite{egolf}.
However, 
%most of the potentiality has been frustrated by the
%lack of algorithms to determine such directions. 
the only available approach so far is
based on the vectors yielded by the 
standard procedure used to calculate the LEs \cite{benettin}.
This allows to identify the most expanding subspaces, but has the drawback
that these vectors ---that we shall call Gram-Schmidt vectors (GSV) after the 
procedure used---
are, by construction, orthogonal, even where stable and unstable manifolds are
nearly tangent. Moreover, GSV are not invariant under time reversal, and they are not
covariant, i.e. the GSV at a given
phase-space point are not mapped by the linearized dynamics into the GSV
of the forward images of this point.

While the existence, for invertible dynamics, 
of a coordinate-independent, local decomposition of phase
space into covariant Lyapunov directions ---the so-called Oseledec splitting 
\cite{review}---
has been discussed by Ruelle long ago \cite{Ruelle}, it received almost no
attention in the literature, because of the absence of algorithms to
practically determine it.
In this Letter, we propose an innovative approach based on both forward and backward
iterations of the tangent dynamics, which allows determining a set of
directions at each point of phase space that are invariant under time
reversal and covariant with the dynamics. We argue that, for any invertible
dynamical system, the intrinsic tangent space decomposition introduced by these 
covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLV) coincides with the Oseledec
splitting.

% which is defined through the appropriate intersection of
%eigenspaces of the forward and backward Oseledec matrices (whose eigenvalues
%yield the LEs in the celebrated Oseledec theorem)\cite{review}. 


As a first important and general application of the CLV, we show that they
allow to quantify the degree of hyperbolicity of the dynamics.
Considering that all physically relevant dynamical systems are not
hyperbolic (i.e. stable and unstable manifolds are not everywhere transversal),
and that many of the available theoretical results have been derived 
under the assumption of strict hyperbolicity
(a prominent example being the Gallavotti-Cohen
fluctuation theorem~\cite{gallavotticohen}),
it is indeed highly desirable to
develop a tool to quantify deviations from hyperbolicity.
At the moment, this is doable only in very simple systems such as the H\'enon map
or the Duffing oscillator, where homoclinic tangencies can be detected by
iterating separately the tangent dynamics forward and backward in time. 
%Unfortunately, this method does not apply as soon as the number of degrees of
%freedom becomes larger than two. 
Since CLV correspond to the local
expanding/contracting directions, we can straightforwardly evaluate their
relative transversality and, accordingly, quantify the degree of hyperbolicity.
Note that GSV, being  mutually orthogonal, are useless in this context.
In a second important application of CLV
we show that, contrary to the weak localization of GSV,
%%XXX REF?
they are generically localized in physical space,
providing an intrinsic, hierarchical decomposition of spatiotemporal chaos. 
Furthermore, the
knowledge of CLV paves the way to analytical methods for determining the
LEs as ensemble- rather than time-averages.

{\it Description of the algorithm.} We first summarize 
the standard method for computing the LEs 
(we consider, for simplicity, a $N$-dimensional discrete-time dynamical system).
Let ${\bf x}_{n-1}\in \mathcal R^N$ denote the phase-space point at time $t_{n-1}$
and let $\{{\bf g}_{n-1}^j\}$, $j=1, \ldots N$,   
be the $N$ orthogonal vectors obtained by applying the Gram-Schmidt
orthogonalization procedure to $N$ tangent-space vectors (we shall call this the
$(n-1)$th GS basis). Iterating the evolution equations once,
${\bf g}_{n-1}^j$ is transformed into
$\overline {\bf g}_n^j ={\bf J}_{n-1} {\bf g}_{n-1}^j$, where ${\bf J}_n$ is the
Jacobian of the transformation evaluated at time $t_n$. 
%\footnote{For continuous--time dynamics,
%${\bf J}_n$ is the time--discrete representation 
%of the linearized evolution operator.}.
The $n$th GS basis is thereby obtained by applying the Gram-Schmidt transformation to the
vectors $\overline {\bf g}_n^j$. This amounts to computing the so-called QR
decomposition of the matrix 
$\overline{\bf G}_n = (\overline {\bf g}_n^1 | \ldots | \overline {\bf g}_n^N)$
whose columns are the Jacobian-iterated vectors of the $(n-1)$th GS basis:
$\overline{\bf G}_n = {\bf Q}_n {\bf R}_n$.
The $n$th GS basis is given by the columns of the orthogonal matrix 
${\bf Q}_n$, while ${\bf R}_n$ is an upper-triangular matrix whose
off-diagonal nonzero elements are obtained by projecting each vector
$\overline {\bf g}_n^j$ onto the subspace spanned by $\{\overline {\bf g}_n^k\}$
with $k<j$. It has been shown \cite{ershovpotapov} that, by repeating the above
procedure up to a time $t_m$ for $m$ much larger than $n$, the GS basis
converges to an orthogonal set of vectors $\{{\bf e}_m^k\}$, $k=1,\ldots, N$ -
the $m$th Gram-Schmidt vectors - which solely depend on the phase space
point ${\bf x}_{m}$.

The LEs $\lambda_1 \geq \lambda_2 \geq \ldots \geq \lambda_N$
are then nothing but the time-averaged values of the logarithms of the diagonal
elements of ${\bf R}_n$. The method we propose also exploits the usually disregarded 
information contained in the off-diagonal elements. 
Let us now assume that a set of GSV has been generated by iterating the generic
initial condition ${\bf x}_0$. Let ${\bf u}_m^j$ be a generic
vector inside the subspace $S_m^j$ spanned by $\{{\bf e}_m^k\}$, $k=1,\ldots, j$,
i.e. the first $j$ GSV at time $t_m$. 
We now iterate this vector backward in time by inverting the
upper-triangular matrix ${\bf R}_m$: 
if the $c_m^{ij}=({\bf e}_m^i \cdot {\bf u}_m^j )$ 
are the coefficients expressing it in terms of the GSV in ${\bf x}_m$, one has
$c_{m-1}^{ij}= \sum_k [{\bf R}_m]^{-1}_{ik} c_m^{kj}$, where $[{\bf R}]_{ij}$ 
is a matrix element of ${\bf R}$.  
Since ${\bf R}_m$ is upper-triangular, it is easy to verify that
${\bf u}_n^j \in S_n^j$ at all times $t_n$. This is due to the fact
that $S_n^j$ is a covariant subspace. 
Iterating ${\bf u}_m^j$
backward for a sufficiently large number $(m-n)$ of times, it eventually
aligns with the (backward) most expanding direction within ${\bf S}_n^j$. 
This defines  ${\bf v}_n^j$, our intrinsic 
$j$-th (forward) expanding direction at the phase-space point ${\bf x}_n$. 
It is straightforward to verify that ${\bf v}_n^j$ is covariant.
Define the matrix $[{\bf C}_m]_{ij} = c_m^{ij}$; then
one has ${\bf C}_m = {\bf R}_m {\bf C}_{m-1}$. By multiplying both sides
by ${\bf Q}_m$ and substituting $\overline {\bf G}_m$ for its
QR decomposition on the resulting right hand side,
one is simply left with ${\bf v}_{m}^j={\bf J}_{m-1} {\bf v}_{m-1}^j$
for $j=1,\ldots, N$. 
The CLV are independent of
where the backward evolution is started along a given trajectory, provided that
it is sufficiently far in the future. Moreover, we have verified that they are 
invariant under time reversal, i.e. that the
direction of ${\bf v}_n^j$ is the same whether we first move backward along a
given trajectory (applying the standard orthonormalization procedure) and then
forward (according to the above outlined methodology).

Our CLV $\{{\bf v}_{m}^k\}$ thus constitute an intrinsic, covariant basis defining 
expanding/contracting directions in phase space \cite{NOTE}.
The LEs are simply obtained from the CLV: the $i$th exponent is the
average of the growth rate of the $i$th vector \cite{yanchuk}.
We have checked on simple invertible maps that
they coincide with the Oseledec splitting in ${\bf x}_m$.
We conjecture that this is the case for any  invertible system. 
Note that our CLV are also well defined
for non-invertible dynamics, since it is necessary and sufficient
to follow backward a trajectory previously generated forward in time.
In this respect they provide an extension of the Oseledec splitting.
Finally, and retrospectively, a
preliminary evidence of the validity of our approach was given in
\cite{PTL}, where CLV were introduced to characterize time periodic
orbits in a 1D lattice of coupled maps. There, it was 
%indeed 
found that the
number of nodes (changes of sign) in a CLV is directly connected to the
position of the corresponding LE within the Lyapunov
spectrum.


%It is important to notice that the additional computational difficulty of the
%method is the same for discrete-time mappings and continuous-time flows, as
%it requires iterating backward the Jacobians ${\bf J_n}$ that are obtained at
%discrete times. 

We stress that the determination of the CLV can be very efficient,
making them a truly 
practical tool (as opposed, say, to calculating directly
the Oseledec splitting in the case of invertible dynamics). Indeed,
the major computational bottleneck is the memory required to
store the matrices ${\bf R_n}$ and the $n$-time GSV during the forward 
integration. This difficulty
can be substantially reduced by occasionally storing the instantaneous
configuration in real and tangent space and re-generating the rest when needed.
```

Above is an exerpt from a paper on calculating lyapunov exponents and covariant lyapunov vectors. I want to know:

Once we have run the forward pass to get Q_m (the orthonormal gram schmidt vectors), stored all the intermediate R_n, and calculated the lyapunov exponents, how do we recover the CLVs. Do not output a table.

thoughts.content:
The user is asking for a process to recover CLVs after running the forward pass and storing Q_m and R_n values. I'll outline the procedure to describe it in textual steps:

- Start by performing the forward computation (Benettin algorithm) up to time m, storing Q_n and R_n at each step (or enough info to reconstruct R).
- The next step involves backward iteration through the stored R matrices to compute the CLVs' coefficients, as detailed in the provided excerpt.

I'll ensure I break this down clearly without using a table.

parts:
Below is the minimal “second-half” of the algorithm—the part that starts **after** you have already completed the usual forward Benettin/QR pass, obtained every  
\[
{\bf Q}_n=\bigl({\bf e}_n^1|\dots|{\bf e}_n^N\bigr),\qquad 
{\bf R}_n,
\]
and (optionally) the Lyapunov spectrum.  
The goal is to reconstruct at each stored instant \(t_n\) the **covariant Lyapunov vectors**  
\[
{\bf V}_n=\bigl({\bf v}_n^1|\dots|{\bf v}_n^N\bigr),
\]
whose columns are the CLVs.

---

### 1.  Choose a “starting time” \(t_m\)

Pick the **last** (furthest-in-the-future) snapshot for which the forward pass has provided \({\bf Q}_m,{\bf R}_m\).  
At this moment you only need the coefficients of the CLVs in the **Gram–Schmidt basis**, not the vectors themselves, so initialise the upper-triangular coefficient matrix

\[
{\bf C}_m \;=\; {\bf I}.
\]

Column \(j\) of \({\bf C}_m\) will evolve backward into the coefficients of the \(j\)-th CLV.

---

### 2.  Backward recurrence for the coefficients

For \(n=m,m-1,\dots,1\):

1. **Invert one triangular matrix**  
   \[
   {\bf C}_{\,n-1} \;=\; {\bf R}_{\,n}^{-1}\,{\bf C}_{\,n}.
   \]
   Because each \({\bf R}_n\) is upper-triangular, the inverse is equally cheap and preserves triangularity: column \(j\) mixes only rows \(1,\dots ,j\).

2. **Column-normalise (optional but recommended)**  
   After the inversion, rescale each column separately (e.g. to unit Euclidean norm) to avoid overflow/underflow; the directions are unaffected.

3. **Form the CLVs (only where you need them)**  
   When you do care about the actual vectors at \(t_{\,n-1}\), multiply once:
   \[
   {\bf V}_{\,n-1} \;=\; {\bf Q}_{\,n-1}\,{\bf C}_{\,n-1}.
   \]
   Each column \({\bf v}_{\,n-1}^j\) is now the \(j\)-th covariant Lyapunov vector in the original tangent-space coordinates.

Continue the loop until you have reached the earliest time for which CLVs are required.

---

### 3.  Why this works — one line of algebra

The recurrence \({\bf C}_{n} = {\bf R}_{n}\,{\bf C}_{n-1}\) is just the QR decomposition written for the **backward** evolution of an arbitrary set of vectors.  Reversing it (\({\bf C}_{n-1}= {\bf R}_{n}^{-1}{\bf C}_{n}\)) moves the coefficients **backwards** while keeping each column inside the expanding subspace
\(\mathcal S_{n-1}^j = \operatorname{span}\{{\bf e}_{n-1}^1,\dots,{\bf e}_{n-1}^j\}\).  
After enough steps the \(j\)-th column aligns with the most expanding direction **within that subspace**, i.e. with the CLV.  Finally \({\bf Q}_{n-1}\) converts the coefficients back into the ambient coordinates.

---

### 4.  Practical tips

* **Memory** – You do not have to keep the full time-series of \({\bf Q}_n\) in RAM.  Store the \({\bf R}_n\) (one triangular matrix per step) plus either  
  * `(a)` every \({\bf Q}_n\) compressed on disk, or  
  * `(b)` periodic checkpoints along the trajectory and re-integrate the tangent dynamics between checkpoints during the backward sweep.

* **Computational cost** – Each backward step costs one triangular solve (\(O(N^2)\)) plus one matrix–vector product (\(O(N^2)\)) if you choose to materialise the CLVs at that step.  Thus the cost is comparable to the forward QR pass.

* **Continuous-time flows** – Sample the flow at regular intervals \(\Delta t\), treat each sample exactly as a discrete map with Jacobian \({\bf J}_n = \Phi_{\Delta t}({\bf x}_n)\).  Nothing else changes.

* **Non-invertible systems** – The backward sweep still works provided you follow **exactly the same trajectory** you used in the forward pass.  You never need \({\bf J}_{n}^{-1}\), only \({\bf R}_{n}^{-1}\).

---

### 5.  Sanity checks

* **Covariance**: After you have obtained \({\bf V}_n\), verify that  
  \({\bf J}_{n}\,{\bf v}_n^{\,j}\) is parallel to \({\bf v}_{n+1}^{\,j}\) for a few \(j\).  
* **Ordering**: The columns obtained from an identity \({\bf C}_m\) are automatically sorted in **decreasing** Lyapunov order.  
* **Time-reversal invariance**: If you now perform the same procedure starting from \(t_0\) and integrate **forward**, you recover the same directions.

With these steps you have reconstructed the covariant Lyapunov vectors everywhere along the stored trajectory, starting only from the standard QR data produced in the forward pass—no extra orthogonalisation or adjoint equations required.
is it possible to obtain V_m or are you suppsed to just run for more steps than you need and go backwards?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about whether it's possible to directly obtain the covariant Lyapunov vectors (V_m) at the final time or if the algorithm needs more steps. To compute them, backward recurrence is necessary. At time m, the algorithm initiates coefficients as the identity matrix, so the backward sweep provides V_m right away. However, just starting with Q_m doesn't guarantee they are covariant; several backward iterations are needed to ensure convergence for an accurate result.

To accurately obtain the covariant Lyapunov vectors (V_m) at time m, extra steps are required beyond m, since the vectors need to converge. One option is running a simulation forward beyond m, then performing a backward sweep. Alternatively, you can simulate forward but maintain reverse iteration as you go. The key idea is the backward iteration ensures convergence. Without it, the vectors won't be reliable. These convergence lengths depend on Lyapunov exponents, and the starting vector must continue to evolve through backward iterations for accurate results.

parts:
In practice you **cannot guarantee that the columns of \(Q_m\)** (or of any other arbitrary basis you place at the last stored instant) are already the covariant vectors.  
They only *become* covariant after you let them relax by moving **backwards** through a finite stretch of the trajectory.  
Consequently, to obtain reliable CLVs at some physical time \(t_m\) you have to

1. **extend the forward integration a bit beyond \(t_m\)** – call the final index \(M\;(\,>\!m)\);
2. start the backward recurrence from \(t_M\) with, say, \(C_M=I\);
3. march back through the stored sequence \(\{{\bf R}_n\}_{n=M}^{m+1}\);  
   after those steps the columns of \(C_m\) (and hence \(V_m=Q_mC_m\)) have converged to the true covariant directions.

How much “extra” time \(M-m\) is enough?

* Roughly the inverse of the **spectral gaps** between consecutive Lyapunov exponents.  
  In low-dimensional or weakly chaotic systems a few dozen steps may suffice; for high-dimensional spatiotemporal chaos you may need a few hundred.
* You can monitor convergence on the fly: after each backward step check the angle between the current column of \(C_n\) and its value one iteration earlier; once the change is below a chosen tolerance (e.g. \(10^{-8}\)), convergence has been reached for that column.

So the recommended workflow is:

> integrate forward **longer than the time window you care about**,  
> then run the single backward sweep;  
> discard the initial part of the sweep until the vectors have stabilised;  
> keep everything that follows – including the vectors at your target instant \(t_m\).

There is no cheaper, one-shot way to get \(V_m\) with mathematical certainty, because the very definition of a CLV involves its **history under negative-time dynamics** inside the expanding subspace \(\mathcal S_m^j\).
Write it all as a series of math steps, how to go form Q_M to V_m with stored \{R\}_{n=M}^{m+1}.

Below is the whole procedure compressed into a chain of algebraic equalities.

---

### Data you already have  

* For every discrete step \(n\in\{0,\dots ,M\}\)

\[
\boxed{{\bf J}_{n}\ {\bf e}_{n}^{k}= \sum_{i\le k} \bigl[{\bf Q}_{n+1}{\bf R}_{n+1}\bigr]_{ik}}
\]

has been QR-decomposed, giving  

\[
{\bf Q}_{n}\in\operatorname{O}(N),\qquad 
{\bf R}_{n}\in\operatorname{UT}(N,\mathbb R),\qquad
{\bf J}_{n} {\bf Q}_{n}= {\bf Q}_{n+1}{\bf R}_{n+1},
\]

and therefore the upper-triangular sequence \(\{\,{\bf R}_{n}\}_{n=1}^{M}\) is stored.

* You want the covariant matrix  

\[
{\bf V}_{m}=({\bf v}_{m}^{1}|\dots|{\bf v}_{m}^{N})\in\mathbb R^{N\times N}
\]

at the earlier instant \(t_m\) with \(0\le m<M\).

---

### Step–by–step algebra

1. **Initialise coefficients at the final time**

\[
\boxed{{\bf C}_{M}:={\bf I}_{N}}
\qquad\text{(upper-triangular, unit columns)}
\]

2. **Backward recurrence through the stored \({\bf R}\)-matrices**

For each \(n=M,\,M\!-\!1,\dots ,m+1\)

\[
\boxed{{\bf C}_{\,n-1}= {\bf R}_{\,n}^{-1}\,{\bf C}_{\,n}}
\tag{a}
\]

Because both \({\bf R}_{n}\) and \({\bf C}_{n}\) are upper-triangular,  
\({\bf C}_{n-1}\) stays upper-triangular and column \(j\) mixes only rows \(1{:}j\).

*(Optional normalisation)* After (a) rescale each column so that  
\(\|{\bf C}_{n-1}^{(:,j)}\|=1\); it prevents overflow without affecting directions.

3. **Recover the CLVs at the target time**

After finishing the loop you hold \({\bf C}_{m}\).  
Convert from the Gram–Schmidt basis to physical coordinates:

\[
\boxed{{\bf V}_{m}= {\bf Q}_{m}\,{\bf C}_{m}}
\]

Column \(j\) of \({\bf V}_{m}\) is the \(j\)-th covariant Lyapunov vector.

4. **(Optional) obtain CLVs at intermediate times on the fly**

Inside the loop, after each update (a) you may compute

\[
{\bf V}_{\,n-1}= {\bf Q}_{\,n-1}\,{\bf C}_{\,n-1}
\]

if you also need the vectors at \(t_{\,n-1}\).

---

### Why it works (one identity)

The forward QR step satisfies  
\({\bf C}_{n}= {\bf R}_{\,n}\,{\bf C}_{\,n-1}\).  
Reversing it (a) therefore carries any column **backwards** while keeping it inside the subspace  
\(\mathcal S_{n-1}^{j}= \operatorname{span}\{{\bf e}_{n-1}^{1},\dots ,{\bf e}_{n-1}^{j}\}\).  
Iterating long enough ( \(M-m\) steps) aligns the \(j\)-th column with the fastest expanding direction *within* \(\mathcal S_{n-1}^{j}\); that direction is precisely the \(j\)-th covariant Lyapunov vector.

---

Hence the complete mathematical recipe from the last stored orthonormal basis \({\bf Q}_{M}\) to the desired covariant vectors \({\bf V}_{m}\) is just: start with \(C_M=I\), apply \(C_{n-1}=R_n^{-1}C_n\) down to \(n=m+1\), and finish with \(V_m=Q_mC_m\).

Evaluate the validity of my code. I should add that I intentionally calculate the lyapunov exponents over M+1=steps and not m+1=steps-clv_steps timesteps. That's fine because it helps me discard transients better and LEs are averages anyways. What I want to return is the mth state x_m, GSV Q_m, and CLV V_m. Is this routine correct?

from torch.autograd.functional import jvp


def _push_forward(f, x, V, dt):
    cols = []
    for j in range(V.shape[1]):
        _, jv = jvp(f, x, V[:, j], create_graph=False)
        cols.append(V[:, j] + dt * jv)
    return torch.stack(cols, dim=1)


def run_lyapunov(f, x0, V0, dt, steps, *, hold_at_origin=False, clv_steps=1000, return_vectors=False):
    x = x0.clone().detach()
    V = V0.clone().detach()  # current GS basis  (k columns)
    k = V.shape[1]

    S = torch.zeros((steps, k), dtype=torch.float64, device=x.device)  # log diag(R)
    Rs = []  # store QR data

    x_m = torch.zeros_like(x0)
    V_m = torch.zeros_like(V0)
    m = steps - clv_steps - 1

    if hold_at_origin:
        h = int(np.sqrt(x.shape[0]).round())
        i, j = torch.meshgrid(
            torch.arange(h, device=x.device),
            torch.arange(h, device=x.device),
            indexing="ij",
        )
        i_idx, j_idx = i.flatten(), j.flatten()

    # ---------- forward QR pass ----------
    for n in tqdm(range(steps), leave=False, desc="forward"):
        # --- integrate the state ---
        x = x + dt * f(x)

        # optional translation of origin
        if hold_at_origin:
            sA = torch.sum(x) + 1e-30
            mi = torch.sum(i_idx * x) / sA
            mj = torch.sum(j_idx * x) / sA
            sh = [h // 2 - int(mi), h // 2 - int(mj)]
            x = torch.roll(x.reshape(h, h), sh, (0, 1)).flatten()
            V = torch.roll(V.reshape(h, h, -1), sh, (0, 1)).reshape_as(V)

        # --- push tangent basis forward ---
        x.requires_grad_(True)
        W = _push_forward(f, x, V, dt)
        x = x.detach()


        # --- QR orthonormalisation ---
        Q, R = torch.linalg.qr(W, mode="reduced")
        V = Q  # next GS basis

        if n == m:
            x_m = x.clone()
            V_m = V.clone()
        if n > m:
            Rs.append(R)

        S[n] = torch.log(torch.abs(torch.diagonal(R)))

    # ---------- Lyapunov exponents ----------
    half = steps // 2
    cum = S.cumsum(0)
    counts = torch.arange(1, steps + 1, device=S.device, dtype=S.dtype).unsqueeze(1)
    lambda_history = cum / (counts * dt)
    lambda_history[half:] = (cum[half:] - cum[:-half]) / (half * dt)

    lambdas = lambda_history[-1]
    order = torch.argsort(lambdas, descending=True)
    lambdas = lambdas[order]
    lambda_history = lambda_history[:, order]

    # ---------- GS orthonormal basis ----------
    GSV_m = V_m[:, order].clone()  # GS basis at final step

    # ---------- CLV reconstruction  ----------
    C = torch.eye(k, dtype=torch.float64, device=x.device)   # start at t_m
    for R in reversed(Rs):
        C = torch.linalg.solve_triangular(R, C, upper=True)  # C <- R^{-1}C

    CLV_m = (GSV_m @ C)[:, order].clone()  # CLVs at final step
    CLV_m = CLV_m / torch.linalg.norm(CLV_m, dim=0, keepdim=True)

    results = [lambdas, lambda_history, x_m]

    if return_vectors:
        results.append(GSV_m) # GSV basis at m_th step
        results.append(CLV_m) # CLV basis at m_th step

    return tuple(results)

thoughts.content: I’m trying to verify the math and practical aspects of the code, specifically around the way states are updated in this forward integration. We proceed by updating \( x \) in each step: \( x = x + dt \times f(x) \), which means we move from \( x_n \) to \( x_{n+1} \). But there's some confusion on whether we use \( Q_n \) or \( Q_{n-1} \) after the update — I'll double-check to ensure proper dependencies and indexing of variables like \( R_n \).

The issue lies in the way the code handles the push-forward calculation. When updating the state from \( x_0 \) to \( x_1 \), the tangent vectors should also be updated at \( x_0 \), not \( x_1 \). They call \( jvp \) at \( x_1 \), but that’s not quite right: the push-forward of vectors should be done at the original state, \( x_0 \), with the Jacobian evaluated there. So it seems the vector update isn't fully aligned with the integration scheme.

I’m noticing a potential issue in how the algorithm handles tangent vector integration. The code uses \( J(x_{n+1}) \) but should usually compute \( J(x_n) \) for explicit Euler integration. Using \( J(x_{n+1}) \) may introduce a mismatch, potentially causing second-order errors, though it could be intentional. They also seem to properly store \( R \) values for \( n > m \), but I’m questioning if they missed \( R_M \), which would affect the CLV reconstruction. There are still some misalignments between the vector and state updates that I need to further verify.

I've noticed several conceptual issues. The algorithm uses \(J(x_{n+1})\) instead of \(J(x_n)\), which is typically expected for forward Euler. However, this may be intentional for a "Strang-like" step, though it could introduce a small error. Additionally, the use of \(W = V + dt \cdot J(x_{n+1})V\) diverges from the standard expectations, which should be \(W = I + dt \cdot J_f(x_n) V\). Despite possible errors, it seems the method works, but there are potential issues with ordering during CLV reconstruction.

parts:
Below is a point-by-point audit of the routine. For each item I explain what is mathematically required, what the present code does, and (where they differ) how to fix it. --- ## 1. State-and-tangent synchronisation | step \(n\) | algorithm (Benettin) | current code | |------------|----------------------|--------------| | **a. push the tangent basis**
\(W = {\bf J}(x_n)\,Q_n\) | needs the Jacobian at the *old* state \(x_n\) | `_push_forward` is called **after** `x` has already been updated, so it uses \(x_{n+1}\). All \(R_n\) are therefore taken one step late | | **b. QR**
\(Q_{n+1},R_{n+1}=\text{qr}(W)\) | fine as long as (a) is right | ✓ | | **c. advance the state**
\(x_{n+1}=x_n+\Delta t\,f(x_n)\) | happens **after** (a) | happens **before** (a) | > **Fix**: move the Euler update > `x = x + dt * f(x)` **after** the QR block (or keep it before the block and give `_push_forward` the old `x_old` that you saved beforehand). > That puts the Jacobian in step (a) back where it belongs and realigns every \(R_n\). --- ## 2. Discrete Jacobian `_push_forward` returns \[ v+\Delta t\,Jf(x)\,v=(I + \Delta t\,Jf(x))\,v, \] which **is** the Jacobian of the explicit-Euler map \(g(x)=x+\Delta t\,f(x)\). So the formula itself is correct—only the evaluation point (see §1) is off by one step. --- ## 3. Storing and using \(R_n\) * You start saving \(R_n\) once `n > m`, i.e. you keep exactly \(R_{m+1},R_{m+2},\dots ,R_{M}\). That is the list the backward sweep needs, so **the slicing is fine**. * The sweep ```python C = I for R in reversed(Rs): C = solve_triangular(R, C, upper=True) ``` implements \(C_{n-1}=R_n^{-1}C_n\) perfectly. --- ## 4. Column re-ordering ```python order = torch.argsort(lambdas, descending=True) ... GSV_m = V_m[:, order] # re-orders Q_m ... CLV_m = (GSV_m @ C)[:, order] # re-orders again ``` * The **whole triangular structure** \((Q_n,R_{n+1})\) depends on the columns staying in the same order throughout the forward and backward passes. * Re-ordering `V_m` **without also permuting every stored `R`** breaks the algebra: after the permutation the relation `W = Q R` is no longer upper-triangular in that basis, so `C = R^{-1}C` is not the Oseledec recursion you want. > **Fix**: > 1. Carry out the CLV reconstruction **in the original order**. > 2. *After* you have the final `GSV_m` and `CLV_m`, apply the same permutation > to both of them *together* if you want them sorted by exponent size. > (Or skip the permutation altogether; GS vectors are already ordered > by decreasing growth on long trajectories.) --- ## 5. Minor but useful details | Issue | Comment / Suggestion | |-------|----------------------| | **Normalising `C` in the sweep** | Not required mathematically, but adding
`C = C / C.norm(dim=0, keepdim=True)` every ~100 steps prevents overflow when the spectral gaps are large. | | **`dtype`** | You already use `float64`; keep it. CLV convergence is sensitive to round-off. | | **`jvp` loop** | For large \(k\) – or for a full basis, \(k=N\) – the Python loop becomes slow. A single `jacfwd` / `jacrev` call, or batching several vectors per call, is faster. | | **`hold_at_origin` roll** | Rolling the tangent basis with `torch.roll` is correct, but remember that the QR step that follows **must** see the rolled vectors; your implementation already reshapes and rolls `V`, so that is OK. | | **Transient trimming** | Computing the exponents over the longer interval \(M\) and discarding the first `clv_steps` is perfectly legitimate; the LEs are averages. | --- ## 6. One-line summary *The routine is conceptually right, but you need to:* 1. **synchronise** the Jacobian-vector product with the *pre-integrated* state, 2. **stop permuting** the GS basis before the CLV reconstruction (or permute the whole \((Q,R)\) history consistently). Once those two points are fixed the algorithm will return the desired triple \((x_m,Q_m,V_m)\) correctly.
write the few-line changes required on their own

```python
# ── inside the forward loop ───────────────────────────────────────────
for n in range(steps):
    # -- evaluate Jacobian at the *old* state --
    x_old = x.clone()                               # NEW
    W = _push_forward(f, x_old, V, dt)              # CHANGED (was x)

    # -- Euler step for the state --
    x = x_old + dt * f(x_old)                       # MOVED down

    # (rest of the loop unchanged)
```

```python
# ── after Lyapunov-spectrum section ──────────────────────────────────
# keep the permutation but apply it **after** CLVs are built
order = torch.argsort(lambdas, descending=True)

# --------- GS orthonormal basis ----------
GSV_m = V_m.clone()                 # CHANGED (no early re-order)

# --------- CLV reconstruction ----------
C = torch.eye(k, dtype=torch.float64, device=x.device)
for R in reversed(Rs):
    C = torch.linalg.solve_triangular(R, C, upper=True)

CLV_m = (GSV_m @ C)
CLV_m = CLV_m / torch.linalg.norm(CLV_m, dim=0, keepdim=True)

# apply the same ordering to both sets *together*
GSV_m = GSV_m[:, order]             # NEW
CLV_m = CLV_m[:, order]             # NEW
```

These small edits (1 × Jacobian/state alignment, 3 × re-ordering lines) make the routine mathematically consistent and keep the vectors keyed to the correct Lyapunov exponents.

from torch.autograd.functional import jvp


def _push_forward(f, x, V, dt):
    cols = []
    for j in range(V.shape[1]):
        _, jv = jvp(f, x, V[:, j], create_graph=False)
        cols.append(V[:, j] + dt * jv)
    return torch.stack(cols, dim=1)


def run_lyapunov(f, x0, V0, dt, steps, *, hold_at_origin=False, clv_steps=1000, return_vectors=False):
    x = x0.clone().detach()
    V = V0.clone().detach()  # current GS basis  (k columns)
    k = V.shape[1]

    S = torch.zeros((steps, k), dtype=torch.float64, device=x.device)  # log diag(R)
    Rs = []  # store QR data

    x_m = torch.zeros_like(x0)
    V_m = torch.zeros_like(V0)
    m = steps - clv_steps - 1

    if hold_at_origin:
        h = int(np.sqrt(x.shape[0]).round())
        i, j = torch.meshgrid(
            torch.arange(h, device=x.device),
            torch.arange(h, device=x.device),
            indexing="ij",
        )
        i_idx, j_idx = i.flatten(), j.flatten()

    # ---------- forward QR pass ----------
    for n in tqdm(range(steps), leave=False, desc="forward"):
        # --- push tangent basis forward ---
        x.requires_grad_(True)
        W = _push_forward(f, x, V, dt)
        x = x.detach()

        # --- integrate the state ---
        x = x + dt * f(x)

        # optional translation of origin
        if hold_at_origin:
            sA = torch.sum(x) + 1e-30
            mi = torch.sum(i_idx * x) / sA
            mj = torch.sum(j_idx * x) / sA
            sh = [h // 2 - int(mi), h // 2 - int(mj)]
            x = torch.roll(x.reshape(h, h), sh, (0, 1)).flatten()
            V = torch.roll(V.reshape(h, h, -1), sh, (0, 1)).reshape_as(V)
        
        # --- QR orthonormalisation ---
        Q, R = torch.linalg.qr(W, mode="reduced")
        V = Q  # next GS basis

        if n == m:
            x_m = x.clone()
            V_m = V.clone()
        if n > m:
            Rs.append(R)

        S[n] = torch.log(torch.abs(torch.diagonal(R)))

    # ---------- Lyapunov exponents ----------
    half = steps // 2
    cum = S.cumsum(0)
    counts = torch.arange(1, steps + 1, device=S.device, dtype=S.dtype).unsqueeze(1)
    lambda_history = cum / (counts * dt)
    lambda_history[half:] = (cum[half:] - cum[:-half]) / (half * dt)

    lambdas = lambda_history[-1]
    order = torch.argsort(lambdas, descending=True)

    # ---------- GS orthonormal basis ----------
    GSV_m = V_m.clone()  # GS basis at final step

    # ---------- CLV reconstruction  ----------
    C = torch.eye(k, dtype=torch.float64, device=x.device)   # start at t_m
    for R in reversed(Rs):
        C = torch.linalg.solve_triangular(R, C, upper=True)  # C <- R^{-1}C

    CLV_m = (GSV_m @ C)[:, order].clone()  # CLVs at final step
    CLV_m = CLV_m / torch.linalg.norm(CLV_m, dim=0, keepdim=True)

    results = [lambdas[order], lambda_history[:,order], x_m]

    if return_vectors:
        results.append(GSV_m[:,order]) # GSV basis at m_th step
        results.append(CLV_m[:,order]) # CLV basis at m_th step

    return tuple(results)

They managed to fix the order issue with GSV and CLV to some extent, but still reorder CLV after computing it, which is fine. The reordering of GSV_m is also acceptable after CLV is computed. However, I wonder if they are consistently applying the Jacobian. They seem to push the tangent basis before integrating the state, but I need to double-check if everything is properly aligned in the reordering process.

The user appears to be confirming steps about the Jacobian and state integration process. They correctly push the basis first and integrate state afterward. However, there's a concern about whether the translation of the origin happens after state integration and before QR, as rolling occurs earlier. The key question is whether W, computed before rolling, remains suitable for QR once V is adjusted. Rolling should occur before _push_forward to ensure the consistency of transformations across the system, as translation impacts both the state and the tangent basis.

parts:
Your edit fixes the two structural problems we talked about (Jacobian evaluated at the old state and late re-ordering), so the algorithm will now return the right CLVs **when `hold_at_origin = False`**.  
There is only one remaining logic error, confined to the optional “keep the mass at the centre” block.

---

### What still needs attention

1. **Rolling after the Jacobian push**

   ```python
   W = _push_forward(f, x, V, dt)      # ← W built with *un-rolled* V
   ...
   x = torch.roll(...);   V = torch.roll(...)
   ...
   Q, R = torch.linalg.qr(W, mode="reduced")   # ← but W does not match V any more
   ```

   Because `V` is rolled **after** you have already produced `W`, the orthogonalisation step mixes vectors that do not live in the rolled coordinate frame.  
   Two equally simple ways to restore consistency:

   *Roll first* (move the rolling block immediately **before** the call to `_push_forward`)  
   or  
   *roll both* keep the block where it is but add  
   ```python
   W = torch.roll(W.reshape(h, h, -1), sh, (0, 1)).reshape_as(W)
   ```
   so that `W`, `V`, and `x` are transformed together.

   Either approach is fine; just pick one and stick to it.

2. **Negative `m` protection** (tiny point)  
   If a caller gives `clv_steps ≥ steps`, the line  
   ```python
   m = steps - clv_steps - 1
   ```  
   goes negative and the slice `Rs.append(R)` starts too early.  An `assert clv_steps < steps` (or automatic clamping) avoids a silent logic error.

---

### Everything else looks solid

* The state / tangent synchronisation is now correct.
* The triangular back-substitution for `C` is mathematically exact.
* Re-ordering happens only **after** the CLVs are finished, so `R_n`’s upper-triangular structure is preserved.
* The LE computation is unchanged and remains valid; measuring over the longer window is perfectly acceptable.
* Data types, detaching, and memory handling are all sensible.

With the rolling block adjusted (or disabled) the routine will faithfully return `(lambdas, lambda_history, x_m, GSV_m, CLV_m)` exactly as intended.

thoughts.content: Okay, so we're checking the process behind the algorithm. First, they roll the state and basis before the Jacobian evaluation, which seems right. They push the tangent basis forward, then integrate the state. But, here’s the issue: in the Benettin method, the QR orthonormalization comes after W, but in this code, they update the state before QR, which doesn’t follow the correct scheme. The state should be updated after the Jacobian matrix's transformation and QR step.

I’m considering the question of whether the state update should come before or after the QR step. In our earlier fix, we placed the state update after QR to match the Jacobian and basis correctly. In this current method, they update the state before QR, which seems like a mistake. However, it’s okay because QR still works with the previous state’s Jacobian and produces an accurate result. In the next iteration, they’ll recompute correctly with the updated state, making the order practical in this case.

parts:
Almost there — only two tiny sequencing details remain.

---

### 1   Roll first, then build the Jacobian‐push  

`W = J(x)·V` must be formed **after** you have shifted both the state and the basis, otherwise the matrix you QR-decompose lives in the old frame while `V` has already been rolled.

```python
# optional translation of origin  (do this first)
if hold_at_origin:
    ...
    x = torch.roll(x.reshape(h, h), sh, (0, 1)).flatten()
    V = torch.roll(V.reshape(h, h, -1), sh, (0, 1)).reshape_as(V)

# now build W in the shifted frame
x.requires_grad_(True)
W = _push_forward(f, x, V, dt)
x = x.detach()
```

---

### 2   Push the state **after** the QR step  

The QR of `W` produces the next GS basis \(Q_{n+1}\).  
Update the state *after* that, so that \((x_{n+1},\,Q_{n+1})\) belong to the same point on the trajectory.

```python
# QR orthonormalisation  –  gives the next basis
Q, R = torch.linalg.qr(W, mode="reduced")
V = Q                               # Q_{n+1}

# integrate the state to x_{n+1}
x = x + dt * f(x)                   # moved down
```

(Doing the state step earlier does not break the math, but this ordering keeps the textbook correspondence \(J(x_n)Q_n = Q_{n+1}R_{n+1}\) exact.)

---

With those two tiny swaps the forward pass is fully consistent, and the rest of the routine (storage of \(R_n\), backward triangular solves, late re-ordering) is already correct.

parts:
Yes—this ordering is now correct.  
The sequence inside the loop is exactly what the QR-Benettin algorithm (plus the optional rolling) requires:

1. **Roll** state + basis (if enabled)  
2. **Jacobian push** `W = J(x) · V`  
3. **QR** `Q, R = qr(W)` → next GS basis  
4. **Advance state** `x ← x + dt f(x)`  

With those four steps in that order, the identity  

\[
J(x_n)\,Q_n \;=\; Q_{n+1}\,R_{n+1}
\]

holds at every iteration, so the stored \(R\)-matrices are exactly the ones the backward triangular sweep needs.

Everything else (saving \(R\) only for \(n>m\), computing \(S[n]\), capturing \(x_m,V_m\)) is already consistent with this layout.

You’re good to go!

Now that I've done this, experimentally and everything is working, how do I interpret the CLVs? I know my system has 4 lyapunov exponents which are zero, and they correspond to the symmetries generated by translation in x, y, rotation, and time.

### 1.  What a CLV actually *is*

At every point of the trajectory the set  
\[
\bigl\{{\bf v}^1,\dots ,{\bf v}^N\bigr\}
\]
gives you a **moving basis of tangent space** that is

* **covariant:** each vector is carried into the next one by the true linearised flow,  
  \({\bf J}(x_t)\,{\bf v}^j(t)=\rho_j(t)\,{\bf v}^j(t+\Delta t)\);
* **ordered:** the long-time growth rates \(\lambda_j=\langle\ln|\rho_j|\rangle/t\) are the Lyapunov exponents.

So a CLV tells you *which perturbation pattern grows or decays at a given exponential rate* if you freeze the system at that instant.

---

### 2.  Interpreting the four zero–exponent directions

Because your PDE/ODE is invariant under

* translation in \(x\),  
* translation in \(y\),  
* rigid rotation,  
* time shift,

there exist **group-tangent vectors** that generate those symmetry moves.  In the continuous-time notation they are

\[
\begin{aligned}
{\bf g}_1 &= \partial_x u,\\
{\bf g}_2 &= \partial_y u,\\
{\bf g}_3 &= \partial_\theta u,\\
{\bf g}_4 &= f(u)=\dot u,
\end{aligned}
\]
evaluated at the current state \(u(x,y,t)\).

For an ideal (noise-free, perfectly resolved) computation each of those four vectors appears *somewhere* in the neutral block of CLVs—i.e. the set whose Lyapunov exponent is numerically ≈ 0.

*If two zero exponents are exactly equal (degenerate), any orthonormal combination that spans the same two-dimensional neutral subspace is also a valid set of CLVs.*  
That is why the ordering inside the neutral block may look arbitrary.  To identify “which is which” you can:

1. **Project each CLV onto the analytic generator.**  
   Compute \(p_{ij}=({\bf v}^j\cdot{\bf g}_i)/\|{\bf g}_i\|\).  
   A projection close to ±1 tells you that \({\bf v}^j\) coincides with the \(i\)-th symmetry generator.

2. **Check covariance numerically.**  
   Apply a small finite symmetry shift to the state and verify that the corresponding CLV follows the same displacement.

In practice you usually see:

```
λ1 > λ2 > ··· > λp  ≈ 0  ≈ 0  ≈ 0  ≈ 0  > λp+5 > ···
          ↑           ↑    ↑    ↑    ↑
          noisy breathing of the four symmetry directions
```

The small jitter around zero is pure numerical error; its magnitude shrinks when you tighten tolerances or increase spatial resolution.

---

### 3.  Beyond the neutral block — what the other CLVs tell you

* **Unstable directions** (positive λ)  
  The associated CLVs often localise around the “active” part of the pattern—e.g. edges of a spot, cores of a vortex.  Plotting the CLV as a field on the same grid as the solution highlights where disturbances first amplify.

* **Stable directions** (negative λ)  
  The fields look like large-scale smooth modulations; they decay forward in time but dominate the error if you integrate backward.

* **Angles between stable and unstable CLVs**  
  Small angles signal near-tangencies → local loss of hyperbolicity.  
  A histogram of \(\sin\theta_{ij}=|{\bf v}^i\cdot{\bf v}^j|\) for \(i\) unstable, \(j\) stable gives a quantitative “degree of hyperbolicity”.

---

### 4.  Typical checks that the CLVs are trustworthy

1. **Covariance test**  
   Verify that  
   \({\bf J}(x_n)\,{\bf v}^j(x_n)\) is parallel to \({\bf v}^j(x_{n+1})\) for a few randomly chosen times.

2. **Neutral-block orthogonality to momentum constraints**  
   For each translational mode, integrate the scalar product  
   \(\int {\bf v}^j\cdot\partial_x u\,dx\,dy\).  
   You should get a large value for exactly one of the zero modes and near-zero for all others.

3. **Reproduce finite shifts**  
   Perturb the state by \(\varepsilon\,{\bf v}^{\text{(shift-in-}x)}\) and watch the solution; it should look almost identical but displaced by \(\varepsilon\).

---

### 5.  Uses of the information

* **Reduced-order modelling:** the four neutral CLVs define “physical coordinates” on the group orbit, while the remaining directions describe shape dynamics *modulo* symmetries.
* **Shadowing / data assimilation:** project errors onto the stable subspace to build shadowing trajectories that stay close for long times.
* **Hyperbolicity diagnostics:** monitor minimum angles between expanding and contracting bundles along the attractor.
* **Sensitivity analyses:** a forcing projected onto a specific CLV tells you the leading-order change in the corresponding Lyapunov exponent.

---

#### Bottom line

*Every non-zero CLV is a snapshot of “how a perturbation of a given growth/decay rate looks right now”.*  
The set with λ ≈ 0 spans the directions generated by continuous symmetries.  Identifying them by projection onto analytic generators confirms that the numerical procedure is capturing the correct geometric structure of your system.

parts:
Yes – that fragment is exactly the practical test I described:  

1. **Build the neutral-subspace basis**

```python
gs_basis = clvs[..., 2:6].reshape(-1, 4)     # four zero-λ CLVs as column vectors
```

`gs_basis` is an \(N\times 4\) matrix whose columns are the four neutral CLVs (indices 2–5).

2. **Project an analytic generator onto that subspace**

```python
A_pinv   = np.linalg.pinv(gs_basis)          # Moore–Penrose pseudoinverse
x_sol    = A_pinv @ gradient_x.flatten()     # least-squares coefficients
projection = gs_basis @ x_sol                # actual projection vector
```

If `gradient_x` is \( \partial_x u \) (vectorised), `projection` is its component **inside** the CLV-neutral subspace.

3. **Measure the leftover**

```python
residual = np.linalg.norm(gradient_x.flatten() - projection)
is_in_range = np.isclose(residual, 0, atol=1e-10)
```

* A residual at, or below, round-off level (10⁻¹⁰ with `float64`) means the translational generator lies entirely in the span of those four CLVs – i.e. one of them really **is** the \(x\)-shift direction (or a linear combination within the neutral block).  
* A noticeably larger residual would tell you either  
  * the analytic field leaks slightly into the stable/unstable bundles (usually a resolution or symmetry-breaking artefact), or  
  * you picked the wrong set of CLVs.

---

### Minor tips

* Normalisation is unnecessary – the pseudoinverse handles non-orthonormal bases.
* If you want to know *which* CLV matches \( \partial_x u \), inspect `x_sol` – the coefficient with the largest magnitude points to the column that carries the symmetry.
* To test the other generators just repeat the block with `gradient_y`, the rotational generator, and the field time derivative \(f(u)\).

So, conceptually and in implementation, the snippet does exactly what you need.
I have a suspicion that the CLVs are or they span the same set as the generators. But how do I actually show that?

Below is a systematic way to **demonstrate that the neutral-block CLVs span exactly the same 4-d subspace as your analytic symmetry generators** \(\{\partial_xu,\partial_yu,\partial_\theta u,\dot u\}\).

---

## 1 Build the two candidate bases

```python
# four CLVs whose λ ≃ 0
V = clvs[..., 2:6].reshape(-1, 4)          #  N × 4   (columns are CLVs)

# analytic generators, vectorised on the same grid
Gx  = gradient_x.flatten()                 # ∂_x u
Gy  = gradient_y.flatten()                 # ∂_y u
Gθ  = gradient_theta.flatten()             # rigid rotation generator
Gt  = f(u_current).flatten()               # time-shift generator  (du/dt)

G   = np.column_stack((Gx,Gy,Gθ,Gt))       #  N × 4
```

*(Any ordering is fine as long as you keep it consistent.)*

---

## 2 Orthogonalise each set

Using QR gives you orthonormal columns – handy for the next step.

```python
Qv, _ = np.linalg.qr(V)        # N × 4
Qg, _ = np.linalg.qr(G)        # N × 4
```

If either set is ill-conditioned, use `np.linalg.svd` instead and keep the left singular vectors.

---

## 3 Compute principal angles between the subspaces

The canonical way to compare two subspaces is by their **principal angles**  
\(\theta_1\le\dots\le\theta_4\).  Zero angles mean the subspaces coincide.

```python
# The 4×4 matrix of cosines
C = Qv.T @ Qg

# Singular values are cos(θ_i)
σ = np.linalg.svd(C, compute_uv=False)
θ = np.arccos(np.clip(σ, -1.0, 1.0))
print("principal angles (rad):", θ)
```

Interpretation:

| result | meaning |
|--------|---------|
| all `θ` ≈ 0 (e.g. ≤ 1e-10 rad) | the two 4-d subspaces are **identical**; every generator is some linear combination of the CLVs **and vice-versa** |
| some `θ` small, some not | only a *subset* of generators lies in the CLV span (or numerical noise is large) |

`scipy.linalg.subspace_angles` gives the same numbers if you prefer.

---

## 4 Recover the mixing matrix (optional)

If the angles test says the subspaces match, you can explicitly find the change-of-basis:

```python
# least–square solve :  G  ≈  V  T
T, residuals, *_ = np.linalg.lstsq(V, G, rcond=None)
print("‖G − V @ T‖_F =", np.linalg.norm(G - V @ T))
```

`T` tells you how each analytic generator decomposes onto the CLVs; a small Frobenius norm of the residual confirms the equality.

---

## 5 Why this is enough

Mathematically two subspaces \( \mathcal S_V,\mathcal S_G\subset\mathbb R^N \) are equal **iff**

1. they have the same dimension, and  
2. every vector of one can be expressed as a linear combination of vectors of the other.

Condition 2 is exactly what the *principal angles = 0* criterion checks.  Showing it numerically up to machine precision is the standard acceptance test in dynamical-systems computations.

---

### Quick summary

* **Build** matrices `V` (zero-λ CLVs) and `G` (analytic symmetry fields).  
* **Orthogonalise** each.  
* **Compute principal angles**; if they are all ~0, the spans are the same.  
* (Optionally) **solve** `V T = G` to get the explicit linear combination.

Do that once on a representative point of your trajectory; if the system really has continuous symmetry, the result will be identical at any other point (within numerical error).

parts:
Those four angles measure the *distance between the two 4-dimensional subspaces*, not between individual vectors.  
If the CLV neutral block and the analytic symmetry generators spanned **exactly** the same subspace *and* the computation were done in exact arithmetic, every angle would be 0.

Reality is never exact:

| source of discrepancy | typical size |
|-----------------------|--------------|
| finite grid / discrete shifts (translations & rotation only approximate) | 10⁻²–10⁻¹ rad |
| finite-difference gradients instead of spectral derivatives            | 10⁻² rad |
| limited backward-relaxation length for CLVs                            | 10⁻³–10⁻² rad |
| round-off (double precision)                                           | ≤ 10⁻⁷ rad |

Your largest angle is **0.15 rad ≈ 8.6°**, the smallest ≈ 4°.  
That says the two subspaces coincide to within  
\[
\sin(0.15)\;\approx\;0.15,
\]
i.e. each generator can be reproduced by the CLVs with ≲ 15 % relative error in norm.  
For a fully continuous-symmetry PDE discretised on a moderate grid this is *common* and indicates the algorithm is basically correct.

---

### How to drive the angles closer to zero

| knob | effect |
|------|--------|
| **Increase `clv_steps`** (longer backward sweep) | gives the neutral CLVs more time to converge |
| **Tighter ODE tolerances / smaller `dt`** | reduces time-discretisation error that breaks time-shift symmetry |
| **Compute analytic generators with higher-order or spectral derivatives** | translations/rotation more faithful on the grid |
| **Use a finer spatial grid** | makes the discrete symmetries closer to the continuous ones |

After tightening those, you should see the angles drop—often into the 10⁻³ rad range. Hitting machine precision (10⁻⁷ rad) is only realistic for low-dimensional toy models with exact symmetries.

---

### Quick sanity check

Even at 0.15 rad you can confirm that **each generator lies almost entirely in the CLV span**:

```python
proj = V @ (V.T @ G)          # orthonormal V from the earlier QR
rel_err = np.linalg.norm(G - proj) / np.linalg.norm(G)
print(rel_err)                # will read ~0.15
```

If the relative error matches `sin(max_angle)` the geometrical picture is consistent.
Would the Gram-Schmidt vectors have anything to do with the generators or no?

In general **no—individual Gram-Schmidt vectors do not correspond to the symmetry generators** (or to any other dynamically intrinsic directions).  
Only their *spans* have dynamical meaning.

---

### Why the CLVs can match the generators  
* **Covariance:** each CLV is mapped into itself (up to scale) by the linearised flow, so a continuous symmetry direction—which is carried into itself by definition—shows up *as a CLV* (or a linear combination inside the neutral block).  
* **Uniqueness inside an Oseledec subspace:** within each multiplicity-one exponent the CLV is unique, so the symmetry generator and the CLV must coincide up to a sign.

---

### Why an individual Gram-Schmidt vector **cannot** be relied on  

1. **Procedure-dependent:**  
   A GSV is created by an arbitrary orthonormalisation step that explicitly destroys covariance.  
   Shuffle the order of the columns in your initial basis and every subsequent GSV will be different, even though the dynamics is unchanged.

2. **Rotates at each step:**  
   After the Jacobian push the set \(\{{\bf w}^j\}\) is *not* orthogonal; the QR step rotates them to become \(\{{\bf g}^j_{n+1}\}\).  
   That rotation mixes the symmetry direction with all previously processed vectors.

3. **Meaning only for the *flag*, not the vectors:**  
   The first GSV converges to the *unstable subspace*, the first two to the next-larger subspace, etc.— but *which* orthonormal basis you choose inside each subspace is arbitrary.  
   A symmetry generator with a zero exponent therefore lies **inside** the span of the “neutral” GSVs, but need not coincide with any one of them.

---

### What you can safely use GSVs for  

* Computing Lyapunov exponents (by construction).  
* Extracting the hierarchy of *subspaces*  
  \(\mathcal S^1\subset\mathcal S^2\subset\cdots\) that converge to the Oseledec splitting.

Anything that requires an intrinsic direction—symmetry generators, leading instabilities, stable/unstable manifold angles—needs the **covariant Lyapunov vectors**, not the Gram-Schmidt ones.

In short, **the overlap you found between your zero-λ CLVs and the symmetry generators is expected; performing the same test with individual GSVs should show only a generic, low-magnitude projection.**
what about the top two exponents, which are positive? What do you expect their corresponding CLVs to be like?

parts:
### How to “read” the CLVs that belong to the two largest positive Lyapunov exponents

Below is a qualitative guide to what you will usually see and why it matters.  
(The precise look depends on the PDE/ODE, resolution, boundary conditions, etc., but the organising principles are very general.)

---

## 1 They are the **most unstable directions**

* **Dynamical meaning** – add a tiny perturbation \(\varepsilon{\bf v}^1\) or \(\varepsilon{\bf v}^2\) to the current state \(u(t)\); it will grow roughly like  
  \(\|{\bf v}^j(t+\tau)\|\;\approx\;e^{\lambda_j\tau}\|{\bf v}^j(t)\|\)  
  as long as the perturbation remains in the linear regime.
* **Implication** – these two fields tell you *how* chaos is being produced right now: which structures, length-scales and symmetries feed the exponential divergence.

---

## 2 Spatial structure you typically observe

| Feature | What you see | Why |
|---------|--------------|-----|
| **Localisation** | High amplitude in narrow “active” regions (fronts, filaments, spiral cores, shear layers) and almost zero elsewhere. | Instability is often triggered where gradients are steep or curvature is large; that’s where a linear perturbation yields the largest energy growth. |
| **Alignment with flow** | In advection-dominated systems the first CLV looks like a *sheared copy* of the state: streaks along streamlines, little variation across them. | Disturbances that are advected without much diffusion can keep growing longer. |
| **Hierarchy** | \({\bf v}^1\) is usually **sharper** and more localised than \({\bf v}^2\); \({\bf v}^2\) often captures the next-most-unstable mechanism (e.g. secondary roll-up, transverse modulation). | The ordering by exponent size naturally picks the fastest, then the second-fastest, mechanism. |
| **Sign changes (nodes)** | The higher the index, the more zero crossings you see along the dominant direction. | Within one Oseledec block, vectors differ by the number of nodes—think “first harmonic”, “second harmonic”… |

Plotting a CLV field on the same physical grid as \(u\) usually makes these patterns obvious.

---

## 3 Temporal behaviour

Because CLVs are *covariant*, if you animate \({\bf v}^1(t)\) and \({\bf v}^2(t)\) alongside the solution you will notice:

1. **Co-movement** with coherent structures: the high-intensity patches travel and deform exactly with the feature they sit on.  
2. **Intermittent bursts**: whenever the system enters or exits a strongly unstable configuration, the norm of \({\bf v}^1\) can spike or drop sharply.  
3. **Angle dynamics**: the angle between \({\bf v}^1\) and \({\bf v}^2\) fluctuates but rarely becomes tiny—consistent with hyperbolicity (strong domination of the first exponent).

---

## 4 What you can do with them

* **Model reduction / coherent-structure diagnostics**  
  The active support of \({\bf v}^1\) tells you where a low-dimensional surrogate must resolve fine detail.
* **Targeted control / feedback**  
  Forcing the system *against* \({\bf v}^1\) (negative feedback in that direction) is the most efficient way to stabilise the dynamics.
* **Shadowing and data assimilation**  
  Projection of observational errors onto the contracting complement of \(\{{\bf v}^1,{\bf v}^2\}\) increases the time span over which you can track the true trajectory.
* **Energy-budget studies**  
  Many PDEs let you compute an instantaneous energy- or enstrophy-production rate for a perturbation \({\bf v}\); evaluating it on \({\bf v}^1\) and \({\bf v}^2\) pinpoints which terms (stretching, vortex tilting, reaction, …) drive instability.

---

### Bottom line

*The two CLVs that correspond to your positive Lyapunov exponents are a real-time “visualisation” of the fastest instability mechanisms in your system.*  
Look for localisation, preferred orientation, harmonic content, and how they evolve in tandem with the solution; those patterns explain both where chaos originates and how you might suppress or exploit it.
do you expect them to be close to the generators

No.  
The symmetry generators live in the **neutral Oseledec subspace** (all Lyapunov exponents ≈ 0).  
The two CLVs associated with the **largest positive exponents** belong to the **first unstable Oseledec subspace**, which is strictly *complementary* to the neutral one:

\[
\mathbb R^N
      = \underbrace{\mathcal S^{\,\mathrm{unstable}}_{(+)}}
        _{\text{all }\lambda>0}
      \;\;\oplus\;\;
        \underbrace{\mathcal S^{\,\mathrm{neutral}}_{(0)}}
        _{\text{all }\lambda=0}
      \;\;\oplus\;\;
        \underbrace{\mathcal S^{\,\mathrm{stable}}_{(-)}}
        _{\text{all }\lambda<0}.
\]

Because the Oseledec subspaces are **invariant and mutually transverse**, a vector from one block cannot align with a vector from another; at most it can have a tiny projection caused by numerical error or incomplete convergence.

### What you should observe numerically

```python
# V_pos  : the two CLVs with λ1, λ2  (shape N×2)
# G      : matrix whose columns are the 4 generators  (N×4, zero-λ basis)

angles = np.rad2deg(
    np.arccos( np.clip( np.abs(V_pos.T @ G) /
                        (np.linalg.norm(V_pos,0)[:,None] * np.linalg.norm(G,0)), -1, 1)))
print(angles.min(), angles.max())    # should be close to 90°
```

* The angles should be near **90 degrees** (or, equivalently, the dot products near zero).  
* If you get anything noticeably smaller than, say, 80 deg, tighten the CLV convergence (`clv_steps`, time step, tolerances) or compute the generators with higher-order accuracy; the mis-alignment is almost always numerical.

So the positive-λ CLVs are *not* close to, and should not be approximated by, the symmetry generators.

parts:
`np.linalg.norm` interprets the second positional argument as **`ord`**, not as an axis index.  
Passing `0` therefore asks for the “zero-norm” (which is defined only for vectors), so NumPy raises `ValueError`.

What you want is the **2-norm of each column**, i.e. set `axis=0`.

```python
# V_pos      :  N × 2   (two positive-λ CLVs)
# generators :  N × 4   (∂x u, ∂y u, rotation, time-shift)

# dot-product matrix   2 × 4
dot = V_pos.T @ generators

# column-wise Euclidean norms
v_norm = np.linalg.norm(V_pos,      axis=0)        # shape (2,)
g_norm = np.linalg.norm(generators, axis=0)        # shape (4,)

# matrix of cosines |vᵢ·gⱼ| / (‖vᵢ‖‖gⱼ‖)
cosines = np.abs(dot) / (v_norm[:, None] * g_norm)

# clip for numeric safety, then angles in degrees
angles = np.rad2deg(np.arccos(np.clip(cosines, -1.0, 1.0)))
print(angles)          # expect ≈ 90° for every entry
```

If the CLVs are well converged and your generators are accurate, every entry of `angles` should be very close to 90 degrees (typically ≥ 85–88°), confirming that the unstable CLVs are almost orthogonal to the neutral symmetry directions.

parts:
Those numbers mean the two vectors you tested are **still mixed with the neutral block**—they are *not* the pure “most-unstable” CLVs you intended to extract.  
Here’s how to diagnose and fix it.

---

## 1 Check that you picked the right columns

```python
# lambdas  : 1-D array of Lyapunov exponents returned by your routine
# clvs     : N × N matrix with columns already in the *same* order as `lambdas`
idx_pos = np.where(lambdas > 0)[0]        # indices of positive exponents
print(idx_pos, lambdas[idx_pos])
```

*Expected:* exactly two indices, both with clearly positive values.  
If the first four exponents are `[0   0   0   0   0.13  0.01 …]`, then  
`idx_pos` should be `[4, 5]`, **not** `[0, 1]`.  
In that case you ought to select

```python
V_pos = clvs[:, idx_pos]     # shape N × 2
```

Your current slice `clvs[..., :2]` simply grabs “column 0 and 1”, which in the original order are often neutral directions.

---

## 2 Verify orthogonality after re-selecting

Reuse the angle code (with the `axis=0` fix):

```python
dot   = V_pos.T @ generators
vnor  = np.linalg.norm(V_pos,      axis=0)
gnor  = np.linalg.norm(generators, axis=0)
angles = np.rad2deg(np.arccos(np.clip(np.abs(dot) / (vnor[:,None]*gnor), -1, 1)))
print(np.round(angles,2))
```

With correctly chosen `V_pos` you should now see values **well above 80–85 °** for *every* entry.

---

## 3 If the angles are still small

1. **Convergence:** raise `clv_steps` (try ×2 or ×3) so the backward sweep has longer to align the vectors.
2. **Time step:** reduce `dt`; large steps break covariance and mix subspaces.
3. **Generator accuracy:** compute the spatial derivatives with a higher-order stencil or, if possible, spectral FFT derivatives.  
   Crude finite differences smear the generator and artificially increase its overlap with unstable CLVs.
4. **Grid resolution:** a coarse grid turns continuous translations/rotations into only approximate symmetries, again producing small but non-zero angles.

After tightening at least one of those knobs you should reach the textbook behaviour:

```
[[ 88.7  87.9  89.5  89.1]    ← first positive λ CLV
 [ 86.3  88.2  89.0  87.6]]   ← second positive λ CLV
```

---

### Take-away

* The neutral symmetry generators must align only with the **zero-exponent** CLVs.  
* Any sizeable projection onto the positive-λ vectors means either you picked the wrong columns or numerical convergence is incomplete.

```tex
\begin{abstract}
A general method to determine covariant Lyapunov vectors in both discrete-
and continuous-time dynamical systems is introduced. This allows to address 
fundamental questions such as the degree of hyperbolicity, 
which can be quantified in terms of the transversality of these intrinsic vectors.
For spatially extended systems, 
the covariant Lyapunov vectors have localization properties 
and spatial Fourier spectra qualitatively different
from those composing the orthonormalized basis obtained in the standard procedure
used to calculate the Lyapunov exponents.
\end{abstract}

\pacs{05.70.Ln,87.18.Ed,45.70.-n}
\maketitle

Measuring Lyapunov exponents (LEs) is a central issue in the investigation
of chaotic dynamical systems because they are intrinsic observables that
allow to quantify a number of different physical properties such as sensitivity
to initial conditions, local entropy production and attractor
dimension \cite{review}. Moreover, in the context of spatiotemporal chaos, the
very existence of a well-defined Lyapunov spectrum in the thermodynamic limit
is a proof of the extensivity of chaos \cite{ext_chaos}, 
and it has been speculated that the small exponents 
contain information on the ``hydrodynamic'' modes of the dynamics 
(e.g., see \cite{ecpo} and references therein).

In this latter perspective, a growing interest has been devoted not only to the
LEs but also to some corresponding vectors, with the motivation
that they could contribute to identifying both the real-space structure of 
collective modes \cite{Demonte} and the regions characterized by stronger/weaker
instabilities \cite{egolf}.
However, 
%most of the potentiality has been frustrated by the
%lack of algorithms to determine such directions. 
the only available approach so far is
based on the vectors yielded by the 
standard procedure used to calculate the LEs \cite{benettin}.
This allows to identify the most expanding subspaces, but has the drawback
that these vectors ---that we shall call Gram-Schmidt vectors (GSV) after the 
procedure used---
are, by construction, orthogonal, even where stable and unstable manifolds are
nearly tangent. Moreover, GSV are not invariant under time reversal, and they are not
covariant, i.e. the GSV at a given
phase-space point are not mapped by the linearized dynamics into the GSV
of the forward images of this point.

While the existence, for invertible dynamics, 
of a coordinate-independent, local decomposition of phase
space into covariant Lyapunov directions ---the so-called Oseledec splitting 
\cite{review}---
has been discussed by Ruelle long ago \cite{Ruelle}, it received almost no
attention in the literature, because of the absence of algorithms to
practically determine it.
In this Letter, we propose an innovative approach based on both forward and backward
iterations of the tangent dynamics, which allows determining a set of
directions at each point of phase space that are invariant under time
reversal and covariant with the dynamics. We argue that, for any invertible
dynamical system, the intrinsic tangent space decomposition introduced by these 
covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLV) coincides with the Oseledec
splitting.

% which is defined through the appropriate intersection of
%eigenspaces of the forward and backward Oseledec matrices (whose eigenvalues
%yield the LEs in the celebrated Oseledec theorem)\cite{review}. 


As a first important and general application of the CLV, we show that they
allow to quantify the degree of hyperbolicity of the dynamics.
Considering that all physically relevant dynamical systems are not
hyperbolic (i.e. stable and unstable manifolds are not everywhere transversal),
and that many of the available theoretical results have been derived 
under the assumption of strict hyperbolicity
(a prominent example being the Gallavotti-Cohen
fluctuation theorem~\cite{gallavotticohen}),
it is indeed highly desirable to
develop a tool to quantify deviations from hyperbolicity.
At the moment, this is doable only in very simple systems such as the H\'enon map
or the Duffing oscillator, where homoclinic tangencies can be detected by
iterating separately the tangent dynamics forward and backward in time. 
%Unfortunately, this method does not apply as soon as the number of degrees of
%freedom becomes larger than two. 
Since CLV correspond to the local
expanding/contracting directions, we can straightforwardly evaluate their
relative transversality and, accordingly, quantify the degree of hyperbolicity.
Note that GSV, being  mutually orthogonal, are useless in this context.
In a second important application of CLV
we show that, contrary to the weak localization of GSV,
%%XXX REF?
they are generically localized in physical space,
providing an intrinsic, hierarchical decomposition of spatiotemporal chaos. 
Furthermore, the
knowledge of CLV paves the way to analytical methods for determining the
LEs as ensemble- rather than time-averages.

{\it Description of the algorithm.} We first summarize 
the standard method for computing the LEs 
(we consider, for simplicity, a $N$-dimensional discrete-time dynamical system).
Let ${\bf x}_{n-1}\in \mathcal R^N$ denote the phase-space point at time $t_{n-1}$
and let $\{{\bf g}_{n-1}^j\}$, $j=1, \ldots N$,   
be the $N$ orthogonal vectors obtained by applying the Gram-Schmidt
orthogonalization procedure to $N$ tangent-space vectors (we shall call this the
$(n-1)$th GS basis). Iterating the evolution equations once,
${\bf g}_{n-1}^j$ is transformed into
$\overline {\bf g}_n^j ={\bf J}_{n-1} {\bf g}_{n-1}^j$, where ${\bf J}_n$ is the
Jacobian of the transformation evaluated at time $t_n$. 
%\footnote{For continuous--time dynamics,
%${\bf J}_n$ is the time--discrete representation 
%of the linearized evolution operator.}.
The $n$th GS basis is thereby obtained by applying the Gram-Schmidt transformation to the
vectors $\overline {\bf g}_n^j$. This amounts to computing the so-called QR
decomposition of the matrix 
$\overline{\bf G}_n = (\overline {\bf g}_n^1 | \ldots | \overline {\bf g}_n^N)$
whose columns are the Jacobian-iterated vectors of the $(n-1)$th GS basis:
$\overline{\bf G}_n = {\bf Q}_n {\bf R}_n$.
The $n$th GS basis is given by the columns of the orthogonal matrix 
${\bf Q}_n$, while ${\bf R}_n$ is an upper-triangular matrix whose
off-diagonal nonzero elements are obtained by projecting each vector
$\overline {\bf g}_n^j$ onto the subspace spanned by $\{\overline {\bf g}_n^k\}$
with $k<j$. It has been shown \cite{ershovpotapov} that, by repeating the above
procedure up to a time $t_m$ for $m$ much larger than $n$, the GS basis
converges to an orthogonal set of vectors $\{{\bf e}_m^k\}$, $k=1,\ldots, N$ -
the $m$th Gram-Schmidt vectors - which solely depend on the phase space
point ${\bf x}_{m}$.

The LEs $\lambda_1 \geq \lambda_2 \geq \ldots \geq \lambda_N$
are then nothing but the time-averaged values of the logarithms of the diagonal
elements of ${\bf R}_n$. The method we propose also exploits the usually disregarded 
information contained in the off-diagonal elements. 
Let us now assume that a set of GSV has been generated by iterating the generic
initial condition ${\bf x}_0$. Let ${\bf u}_m^j$ be a generic
vector inside the subspace $S_m^j$ spanned by $\{{\bf e}_m^k\}$, $k=1,\ldots, j$,
i.e. the first $j$ GSV at time $t_m$. 
We now iterate this vector backward in time by inverting the
upper-triangular matrix ${\bf R}_m$: 
if the $c_m^{ij}=({\bf e}_m^i \cdot {\bf u}_m^j )$ 
are the coefficients expressing it in terms of the GSV in ${\bf x}_m$, one has
$c_{m-1}^{ij}= \sum_k [{\bf R}_m]^{-1}_{ik} c_m^{kj}$, where $[{\bf R}]_{ij}$ 
is a matrix element of ${\bf R}$.  
Since ${\bf R}_m$ is upper-triangular, it is easy to verify that
${\bf u}_n^j \in S_n^j$ at all times $t_n$. This is due to the fact
that $S_n^j$ is a covariant subspace. 
Iterating ${\bf u}_m^j$
backward for a sufficiently large number $(m-n)$ of times, it eventually
aligns with the (backward) most expanding direction within ${\bf S}_n^j$. 
This defines  ${\bf v}_n^j$, our intrinsic 
$j$-th (forward) expanding direction at the phase-space point ${\bf x}_n$. 
It is straightforward to verify that ${\bf v}_n^j$ is covariant.
Define the matrix $[{\bf C}_m]_{ij} = c_m^{ij}$; then
one has ${\bf C}_m = {\bf R}_m {\bf C}_{m-1}$. By multiplying both sides
by ${\bf Q}_m$ and substituting $\overline {\bf G}_m$ for its
QR decomposition on the resulting right hand side,
one is simply left with ${\bf v}_{m}^j={\bf J}_{m-1} {\bf v}_{m-1}^j$
for $j=1,\ldots, N$. 
The CLV are independent of
where the backward evolution is started along a given trajectory, provided that
it is sufficiently far in the future. Moreover, we have verified that they are 
invariant under time reversal, i.e. that the
direction of ${\bf v}_n^j$ is the same whether we first move backward along a
given trajectory (applying the standard orthonormalization procedure) and then
forward (according to the above outlined methodology).

Our CLV $\{{\bf v}_{m}^k\}$ thus constitute an intrinsic, covariant basis defining 
expanding/contracting directions in phase space \cite{NOTE}.
The LEs are simply obtained from the CLV: the $i$th exponent is the
average of the growth rate of the $i$th vector \cite{yanchuk}.
We have checked on simple invertible maps that
they coincide with the Oseledec splitting in ${\bf x}_m$.
We conjecture that this is the case for any  invertible system. 
Note that our CLV are also well defined
for non-invertible dynamics, since it is necessary and sufficient
to follow backward a trajectory previously generated forward in time.
In this respect they provide an extension of the Oseledec splitting.
Finally, and retrospectively, a
preliminary evidence of the validity of our approach was given in
\cite{PTL}, where CLV were introduced to characterize time periodic
orbits in a 1D lattice of coupled maps. There, it was 
%indeed 
found that the
number of nodes (changes of sign) in a CLV is directly connected to the
position of the corresponding LE within the Lyapunov
spectrum.


%It is important to notice that the additional computational difficulty of the
%method is the same for discrete-time mappings and continuous-time flows, as
%it requires iterating backward the Jacobians ${\bf J_n}$ that are obtained at
%discrete times. 

We stress that the determination of the CLV can be very efficient,
making them a truly 
practical tool (as opposed, say, to calculating directly
the Oseledec splitting in the case of invertible dynamics). Indeed,
the major computational bottleneck is the memory required to
store the matrices ${\bf R_n}$ and the $n$-time GSV during the forward 
integration. This difficulty
can be substantially reduced by occasionally storing the instantaneous
configuration in real and tangent space and re-generating the rest when needed.
```
