From the energy inequality, we see that the rate of convergence toward the asymptotic states occurs on the viscous time scale t ∼ O(1/ν), which in the weakly viscous
regime in which turbulent fluids are typically studied is enormously long. However,
in numerical experiments on two-dimensional turbulent flows, one sees that on time
scales much shorter than the viscous time scale characteristic structures emerge which
then come to dominate the flow for very long periods of time, until one finally reaches
the asymptotic state. The goal in the present section is to describe some recent work
which proposes an explanation of the emergence of these intermediate time scales
based on dynamical systems theory.
20
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 21 / 42>

In order to gain some insight into what the metastable states and their associated
time scales are in the NSE, we first review some of the numerical results on this
system. One of the starting points of Beck’s and my work were the investigations
of Yin, Mongomery and Clercx [YMC03]. While their numerical experiments are
consistent with an eventual convergence of solutions to zero, much more striking is
that characteristic structures like vortex dipole pairs or “bar states” (shear flows, in
which the vorticity contours are constant in one direction) emerge quickly from an
initially very disordered state, and then dominate the subsequent evolution of the
flow for very long times.
Insert figures from [YMC03] here if permission is granted.
In the numerics of [YMC03], the most common metastable states that are observed in the system are the dipole states - only with rather carefully prepared initial
conditions are the bar states observed. However, if instead of considering the equation
on a square domain as in [YMC03], one considers the equation on a rectangular domain, the numerical experiments of Bouchet and Simonnet [BS09], indicate that the
bar states can become the dominant metastable states. Furthermore, these states are
sufficiently stable that they continue to dominate the evolution even if the equation
is subjected to a random force. While the random force may cause an apparently
random switching between the bar and dipole states, for the great majority of the
time, the system is in one or the other of these two states.
The goal, in the remainder of this section is to propose an explanation for the rapid
appearance and long persistence of these families of solutions of the two-dimensional
NSE. In [BW11b], Beck and I proposed a dynamical systems explanation for similar
families of metastable states in Burgers equation. These states, and their importance
for the dynamics of the system, were first systematically investigated by Kim and
Tzavaras in [KT01], where they are called “diffusive N-waves”. Our explanation
of the metastable behavior in Burgers equation began by showing that (in scaling
variables, similar to those used in the previous section) there was a one-dimensional
invariant manifold in the infinite dimensional phase space of the equation which is
completely filled with fixed points and these fixed points represent the only possible
long-time asymptotic states of the system. These are analogous to the family of Oseen
vortices in the 2D NSE. If one linearizes about one of these fixed points one finds the
spectrum of the linearized operator has a zero eigenvalue corresponding to motion
along this manifold. The remainder of the spectrum lies strictly in the left halfplane. The next smallest eigenvalue is a simple eigenvalue λ = −1/2, with the rest
of the spectrum having more negative real parts. Locally, invariant manifold theory
allows one to construct a one-dimensional manifold tangent at the fixed point to the
eigenfunction corresponding to this eigenvalue. Using the Cole-Hopf transformation,
Beck and I extended this manifold globally and proved that these manifolds are
normally stable - that is, if one enters a neighborhood of the manifold, one will
remain in a neighborhood of the manifold for all subsequent times. We also showed
21
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 22 / 42>

that this manifold consists of exactly the diffusive N-waves previously identified as
the important metastable states in Burgers equations by [KT01]. Thus, we referred to
these manifolds as the “metastable manifolds”. The final step in our construction was
to show that “almost every” (in a sense made precise in [BW11b]) initial condition
gives rise to a solution of Burgers equation which approaches one of these metastable
manifolds on a short time scale. They evolve (due to the stability properties of the
manifolds) slowly along the manifold until they eventually approach the long-time
asymptotic state on the center manifold. If we represent this scenario graphically,
we obtain the following picture of the phase space of the weakly viscous Burgers
equation:
Figure 2: The phase space of the weakly viscous Burgers equation, showing the
metastable manifolds of diffusive N-waves which govern the intermediate asymptotics.
Comparing this with Figure 1, we see that in this case we have a much more
complete picture of the phase space structures which organize both the long-term
and intermediate asymptotics, and we would now like to extend as much as possible
of this model to understand the appearance of metastable states in the 2D NSE.

L = D + A (57)

Suppose that λ is an eigenvalue of L with normalized eigenvector v. Then we have

Adding these two expressions together and dividing by 2 we find

where the last inequality comes from the bound on the eigenvalues of D and the fact

In physical terms this means somewhat surprisingly that if we have a small, stable, symmetric dissipative linear operator, and add to it a skew-symmetric piece, a
situation which comes up frequently in fluid mechanics when we linearize about some
non-trivial solution of the NSE, we cannot destabilize the system, no matter how large
the skew-symmetric piece is. In fact, what may happen is that the skew-symmetric
piece, even though its own eigenvalues all lie on the imaginary axis, serves to further
stabilize the system.
One example where this seems to occur is in the linearization of the 2D NSE in
the whole plane about the Oseen vortex solutions that were discussed in the previous section. In that the case, the dissipative diagonal part again just comes from
the Laplacian term in the vorticity equation, while the skew-symmetric piece comes
from the linearization of the nonlinear terms about the vortex. The stability properties of this linearization were first investigated numerically by Prochazka and Pullin
[PP95] who found that as the Reynold’s number increased, (which means that the
skew-symmetric piece of the operator became larger and larger with respect to the
symmetric piece) the real part of almost all the eigenvalues of the linearization became increasingly negative – i.e. the vortex becomes more and more stable. The few
eigenvalues whose real parts don’t become more negative are fixed, independent of
the Reynold’s number and correspond to special, exact, symmetric solutions of the
NSE.
A proposal to theoretically explain this stability phenomenon was first proposed
by Gallagher, Gallay and Nier [GGN09] who linked this behavior to the hypercoercivity method developed by Villani [Vil09] and were able to prove rigorously
that this “enhanced stability” occurs in a model problem. More recently, W. Deng
[Den12], [Den11], has extended this method to the actual linearization about an Oseen vortex, at least for modes with a sufficiently strong angular dependence (i.e. if
one expands the perturbation in a Fourier series in polar coordinates of the form
w(r, θ) = P
n wˆn(r) exp(inθ), then n is required to be sufficiently large.)

Because of the difficulty in obtaining information about the decay rates of the
evolution generated by Lˆ`
ν,A˜
from either the spectrum or pseudo-spectrum of the
operator at any fixed time, we will instead study the evolution with the aid of the
hypercoercivity method developed by Villani [Vil09]. This method was developed to
deal specifically with evolutions generated by operators of the form L = A∗A + B,
where B is skew-symmetric. The method can account for the enhanced stability of
the sort we observe by exploiting the lack of commutativity between A and B. This
point is crucial – if [A, B] = 0, we could simultaneously diagonalize the two operators
and wouldn’t observe an qualitative difference in the behavior of the real parts of the
eigenvalues of A∗A and A∗A + B. Villani systematized this by considering the time
decay of a special functional which incorporates this non-commutativity and then
relating this functional to more standard norms of solutions.

Thus we see that the interplay between the symmetric and anti-symmetric parts

states that is much faster than suggested by viscous effects alone. For instance, for
a Reynold’s number of ∼ 104, (in the non-dimensionalized variables in which we are
working, this would be ν ∼ 10−4), these estimates suggest an approach toward the
metastable solutions like bar states on a time scale of the order of τmeta ∼ 100 time
units, rather that the 10, 000 time units expected if the convergence were governed by
the viscous time scale. We note that these convergence rates and Reynold’s numbers
are qualitatively similar to those observed in numerical simulations of these systems.
31
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 32 / 42>

Of course the picture in the case of metastable behavior for the 2D NSE is still far
less complete than for Burgers equation. The most important missing piece is the fact
that so far, the rigorous estimates only apply to the approximation of the true linear
evolution obtained by dropping the nonlocal term in the equation. However, as we
have seen from the numerical computations presented above, the spectral properties
of the operator with or without the nonlocal term are very similar, and we hope that
the sort of techniques Deng developed in [Den11] will also apply here and allow us to
treat the full linearized operator.
A second important difference between Burgers equation and the 2D NSE is that
in Burgers equation the viscous N-waves are the only metastable states for almost
all solutions, but for the NSE there are other candidates, such as the dipole states
observed in numerics (see Remark 12), or the states discussed in Remark 11 which
like the bar states only depend on one of the two spatial variables. This means that
the final picture of metastability for the NSE will undoubtedly be more complicated
than the simple picture in Figure 2 for Burgers equation. Nonetheless, we feel that
these dynamical systems ideas can yield important simplifying insights into the intermediate asymptotics of this important physical system and can explain how time
scales much shorter than the viscous time scales can arise from the operators which
have a small, symmetric dissipative piece, and a large, anti-symmetric component,
which arise frequently in the study of fluid motions.
4 Finite Dimensional Attractors for the NavierStokes equations
In the two previous sections we focussed on the behavior of the two-dimensional
Navier-Stokes equations in the absence of forcing and studied the types of structures
that emerged on intermediate and long time scales. In the present section we consider
solutions of the equation when it is subjected to external forcing. In practice, such
forcing might arise through shearing at the boundaries of the domain, as is the case
in the Taylor-Couette experiment, but as is often done in theoretical studies we will
allow for a general body force, i.e. we will consider the form of the equations in (10)
and (11).
∂tu + u · ∇u = ν∆u − ∇p + g (70)
∇ · u = 0 . (71)
Here the forcing term g is some general vector valued function whose smoothness we
specify below.
Numerical studies show that even in the presence of certain types of forcing,
the structures we studied in previous sections may still play a dominant role in the
dynamical behavior of the system [BS09]. However, in this section we focus on more
general properties of the system such as the existence and dimension of the attractor

previous sections and several excellent monograph length reviews of these results
already exist [Rob01], [DG95].
While most investigations of these questions work directly with the fluid velocity,
in order to keep the discussion as close as possible to prior sections we will continue to
work with the vorticity formulation of the problem. This has the disadvantage that
we are restricted essentially to domains without boundary and thus we focus here as
in section three on a rectangular domain with periodic boundary conditions, so we

As noted in the introduction, in infinite dimensional systems, the existence of
an absorbing ball is not enough in itself to guarantee an attractor. We much show
that the absorbing set is also (pre-)compact in L
2
. One does this by showing the
boundedness of the absorbing ball in Hs, with s ≥ 1, and using the fact that Hs
is compactly embedded in L
2
. The boundedness of the Hs norm follows by energy
estimates similar to those in (74)-(76). They are somewhat more complicated in this
case though because the nonlinear term no longer vanishes as in (75). One still obtains
a bound on the Hs norm though and as a consequence the existence of a bounded,
compact attractor for the forced two-dimensional NSE. In fact, in two-dimensions,
there is a whole sequence of energy estimates linking and bounding the various Sobelev
norms of the solution - for an explication of these estimates, sometimes known as the
ladder theorems, see [DG95].
As discussed in the introduction, one advantage of the existence of an attractor is
that it often allows one to focus attention on a much smaller dimensional system than
the original, infinite dimensional PDE. In fact, the attractor for the two-dimensional
NSE is finite dimensional and one can estimate its dimension in terms of the forcing
function f. This fact was first established for a class of reaction-diffusion equations
by Mallet-Paret [MP76]. In the context of the two-dimensional NSE is first studied
by Constantin and Foias, [CF85]. It is well known that the attractor of a chaotic
dynamical system is often a fractal set and so to measure it, we must use a fractal
dimension. There are several common fractal dimensions including the Hausdorff
dimensional and the capacity dimension. Estimates of the both these quantities
exist in the case of the attractor in the two-dimensional NSE, but we’ll focus on the
capacity here because it is the simplest to define. Given a set A in the phase-space of
our PDE, define N(r) = min number of balls of radius r needed to cover A. Then
the capacity dimension of A is defined to be:
dC(A) = lim sup
r→0

. (78)
It is easy to check that if one takes a segment of a curve or surface in R
d
, the capacity dimension gives the usual and expected values of 1 and 2 respectively. Suppose
now that we consider the attractor for the two-dimensional NSE. The basic idea relating the dimensional estimates to the dynamics of the system is the following. Suppose
one covers the attractor with d-dimensional balls of radius r. On can show that if
the attractor is finite dimensional it suffices to use finite (although perhaps large)
34
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 35 / 42>

dimensional balls to compute the dimension. If one considers how these balls will
be distorted by the flow, say by the time-one map of the system, they will typically
be elongated in some directions, corresponding to the chaotic stretching that occurs
in the attractor. However, the high-frequency modes in the Navier-Stokes equation
are very strongly damped, and if we choose d, the dimension of the covering balls,
sufficiently large, the number of contracting directions will overwhelm the effect of
the expanding directions and result in the total volume of the ball shrinking. The
capacity is defined in terms of the limit as the radius of the balls tends to zero so
we are most interested in the action of the flow on balls of very small radius. In this
limit, the action of the flow is well approximated by the linearization of the flow,
which will distort our original ball into a d-dimensional ellipsoid. The lengths of the
axes of this ellipsoid can then be related to the radius of the original ball by the
singular values of the linearized system, which are in turn related to the Lyapunov
exponents of the dynamical system. If the Lyapunov exponents of the system are
µ1 ≥ µ2 ≥ . . . , (where we have listed the exponents along with their multiplicity),
then the shortest axis of the deformed ellipsoid should have length ∼ reµd, and the
volume on the ellipsoid should be approximately ∼ r
d
e
µ1+...µd
. This in turn gives a
recursion relation between N(r) and N(e
µd ), which can then be used to evaluate the
lim sup in (78). The details of this calculation are very clearly explained in( [DG95],
p. 67) and lead to an estimate of the dimension in terms of the attractor. 1
There are a number of points that must be addressed in order to make this argument rigorous including:
• The Lyapunov exponents concern the asymptotic growth rates of the linearized
flow, not the amount of growth or shrinking that occurs in the time-one map.
• Typically, the Lyapunov exponents will depend on the initial point we choose,
so it’s not clear why this argument leads to a uniform estimate on the dimension
of the attractor.
• Finally, we would like to have an estimate on the attractor dimension in terms
of accessible quantities in the equation, like the viscosity, ν, or the forcing f,
rather than generally unknown Lyapunov exponents.
Constantin and Foias address the first two points by introducing global Lyapunov
exponents. They consider the usual definition of the Lyapunov exponents in terms of
the growth rates of n-dimensional volumes induced by the linearized flow, but before
taking the infinite time limit of these growth rates, they take the supremum of the
growth rates over the attractor. This gives an estimate of the growth rate independent
of the starting point, but might lead to an overestimate of the dimension. They also
give rigorous estimates relating the size of a ball of radius r, transported for a finite
1The link between the attractor dimension and the Lyapunov exponents was first proposed by
Kaplan and Yorke, [KY79], and is often known as the Kaplan-Yorke formula.

the Kaplan-Yorke formula for infinite dimensional systems like the NSE.

Remark 19. Bounding the dimension of the attractor is one way to quantify the
essentially finite dimensional nature of the two-dimensional NSE semi-flow. Another
approach focuses on showing that there is a finite number of determining modes or
determining nodes. In this case, one asks whether or not the knowledge of the behavior
of the projection of the solution on a finite number of modes, or its value at a finite
number of points, is sufficient to determine its long time behavior. More precisely, let
Pd be the projection onto an d-dimensional subspace discussed above. One says that
the system has d determining modes if for some choice of Pd, any two solutions ω(t)
and ω˜(t) for which

with a similar definition for determining nodes. Note that this definition does not
imply that given a knowledge of the first d modes of the system we can reconstruct the
remaining modes, but merely that those (infinitely many) other modes cannot change
the long-term asymptotics of the solution.
The first estimates establishing that the solutions of the two-dimensional NSE had
a finite number of determining modes were by Foias and Prodi [FP67]. More recently,
Jones and Titi, [JT93] have shown that the for periodic boundary conditions, the
number of determining modes is bounded by

While the finite dimensionality of the attractor for the two-dimensional NSE implies that the asymptotic behavior is determined by the motions on some “small”
piece of the phase space, it doesn’t immediately imply that there is a smooth finite
dimensional dynamical system whose motion reproduces the long-time behavior of
the NSE. The reason is that one knows very little about the structure of the attractor
and in fact, for chaotic systems, it is expected to be a complicated, fractal set. Thus,
simply restricting the NSE to the attractor will not generally lead to a smooth, finite
dimensional, dynamical system. An alternate approach which has been pursued is to
attempt to construct a finite dimensional manifold which is:
• smooth, or at least Lipshitz,
• invariant with respect to the semi-flow defined by the NSE, and
• attracts any solution of the equation at an exponential rate.
Such manifolds, if they exist, are called inertial manifolds.
If a PDE possesses an inertial manifold, then by its invariance and attractivity, the
attractor must lie inside it. Thus, by restricting the PDE to the inertial manifold one
obtains a smooth (or at least Lipshitz), finite dimensional dynamical system which
captures all the asymptotic behavior of the original, infinite dimensional system.
Inertial manifolds bear much resemblance to center manifolds in finite dimensional
systems of ordinary differential equations. Recall that the existence theory for center
manifolds requires that the “spectral gap”, that is, the difference between the real
parts of the stable and unstable eigenvalues and the center eigenvalues, must be large
in comparison with the Lipschitz constant of the nonlinear term in the equation.
In the inertial manifold case, this becomes the requirement that there be a large
gap between the eigenvalues corresponding to modes related to the inertial manifold
37
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 38 / 42>

and those “off” the manifold. Typically the distinction between these two sets of
modes is expressed by writing the inertial manifold is written as a graph of a function
whose domain is the span of the first set of these modes and whose range is the span
of the modes off the manifold. The size of the gap is again related to the properties
of the nonlinear term, but are more complicated than those in the ODE case because
the nonlinear term in the PDE is often not Lipshitz on the whole phase space of
the system. For example, consider the nonlinear term in the vorticity equation (73).
The presence of the derivative in the nonlinearity means it is not even defined on the
whole phase space, L
2
(T
2
δ
), let alone Lipschitz. This lack of smoothness results in
much more stringent spectral conditions than in the center manifold case.
For nonlinear terms of the sort that appear in the NSE, the best estimates to date
for the spectral gap require that if the eigenvalues of the linear part of the equation
are ordered as 0 ≥ −λ1 ≥ −λ2 ≥ . . . , then proof of existence for the inertial manifold
requires that for a manifold on dimension N, one must have:
λN+1 − λN ≥ K(λ
1/2
N+1 + λ
1/2
N ) . (84)
For (73), the eigenvalues of the linear part can be explicitly computed as ν(m2+(`/δ)
2
,
and one sees that the large gaps required by (84) do not exist. As a consequence, there
is no proof to date, that the two-dimensional NSE possesses an inertial manifold.
There are, however, large classes of dissipative PDEs for which the existence of
an inertial manifold has been proven. Most of these fall into one of two categories:
1. 1-dimensional equations: In one dimension, if one considers a PDE with linear
part
∂tu = ν∂r
xu , (85)
with periodic boundaries on the interval [−π, π], the eigenvalues are −λn =
−νn2r. Thus, for r > 1/2, one obtains arbitrarily large gaps between eigenvalues
as n grows. Using this growth, the existence of inertial manifolds for equations
like the Kuramoto-Sivishinsky and Cahn-Hilliard, [FST85], [FST88], [CFNT89].
2. Equations with “nicer” nonlinear terms: If the nonlinear term in the equation
is a smooth function on the phase space of the equation, as is true for many
reaction-diffusion equations, the spectral gap condition can be greatly weakened
and the existence of inertial manifolds for many two-dimensional domains, and
even some special three-dimensional domains has been established, [MPS88].
In conclusion, we have seen that the tools of dynamical systems theory provide
a number of insights into the qualitative behavior of solutions of dissipative PDEs,
especially the two-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations. The identification of finite
dimensional invariant structures in the infinite dimensional phase space of these systems, be they attractors, or invariant manifolds, allow one to better understand the
38
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 39 / 42>

long-time asymptotic behavior of both the forced and unforced Navier-Stokes equations, as well as providing a way of understanding the emergence of intermediate time
scales in these systems.

thoughts.content: The proof discussed the absorbing set B_eps, but there are gaps. It doesn’t show that for any bounded set, there exists a time when it enters B_eps, only for B_r. It also doesn’t prove precompactness. There’s a need to confirm the global existence of the flow and handle absolute values properly. The handling of negative minima is incomplete, and the assumption on smoothness for min/max derivatives might not be valid. Overall, the proof needs more rigorous checks and clearer presentation. parts:
### Short verdict  
* **A) Correct?** – *Essential idea* yes, but a few technical slips need patching.  
* **B) Complete?** – Not yet.  You still have to address several routine-but-essential points that Temam’s definition requires.  See details below.

---

## 1.  What works

| step in your note | comment |
|-------------------|---------|
| Choice of the cube \(\mathcal B_\varepsilon\) | In a finite–dimensional phase space (\(\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\)) a closed, bounded set **is automatically compact**, so once you show it is absorbing you are done on the “compact’’ part. |
| Differential inequalities for \(M(t)\) | From  \(\dot M \le 1-M\) you obtain \(M(t)\le 1+(M(0)-1)e^{-t}\).  This is exact and immediately shows \(M(t)\downarrow 1\). |
| Differential inequalities for \(m(t)\) | \(\dot m \ge -m\) implies exponential drift of \(m(t)\) towards \(0\).  The idea is sound and gives the entrance time estimate. |
| Conclusion “there exists \(t^{*}\) after which the orbit lies in \(\mathcal B_\varepsilon\)” | Once the two scalar inequalities are cleaned up (see §2) the statement follows.  So an **absorbing** set has indeed been identified. |

---

## 2.  Points that need fixing

| issue | what to add / modify | why |
|-------|----------------------|-----|
| **Sign of \(m(0)\)** | Replace  \(\ln\!\Bigl(\dfrac{m(0)}{\varepsilon}\Bigr)\) with  \(\ln\!\Bigl(\dfrac{|m(0)|}{\varepsilon}\Bigr)\).  Show explicitly that if \(m(0)<0\) then \(m(t)=-|m(0)|e^{-t}\nearrow 0\). | Your current logarithm is undefined when \(m(0)<0\).  The absolute value cures this and yields the correct entrance time \(\displaystyle t\ge \ln \frac{|m(0)|}{\varepsilon}\). |
| **Generality of initial data** | Right now you assume \(A(0)\in\mathcal B_{r}\) for some \(r>\varepsilon\).  To meet Temam’s definition every *bounded* set \(D\subset\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\) must be absorbed.  Add one sentence: “Any bounded set is contained in a cube \(\mathcal B_{R}\); applying the same inequalities with \(R\) in place of \(r\) gives an entrance time that depends only on \(R\).’’ | Needed for the absorbing–set property (Definition 1 on p.​3 of the PDF) citeturn0file0. |
| **Invariance after the first hit** | Prove \(m(t)\ge -\varepsilon\) and \(M(t)\le 1+\varepsilon\) for *all* \(t\ge t^{*}\) (just re-use the same inequalities with new initial data \(m(t^{*}),M(t^{*})\)). | An absorbing set in Temam’s sense is not required to be strictly invariant, but pointing this out avoids confusion and shows the cube works for all later times. |
| **Regularity justification** | Briefly cite the existence of the (semi)flow and explain why \(M(t)\) and \(m(t)\) are differentiable a.e. (standard ODE comparison or Clarke sub-differentials in finite dimension). | Readers unfamiliar with Lenia might wonder why \(\dot M,\dot m\) exist; two lines suffice. |
| **Compactness remark** | Add: “Because \(\mathcal B_\varepsilon\subset\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\) is closed and bounded, the Heine-Borel theorem makes it compact; hence the absorbing set is compact.” | This addresses the “compact’’ half of “compact absorbing set’’ explicitly. |

---

## 3.  What is still missing for **completeness**

1. **Well-posedness of the semiflow**  
   Temam’s framework presupposes that the mapping  
   \[
     \Phi_t:A(0)\mapsto A(t)\quad (t\ge 0)
   \]
   is a strongly continuous semigroup on the phase space.  Supply a reference or a short argument that the discretised Asymptotic-Lenia update rule indeed generates such a semiflow.

2. **Statement of the definition you use**  
   It helps the reader if you quote exactly Temam’s wording (Definition 1, p.​3) citeturn0file0.

3. **Choice of \(\varepsilon\)**  
   Clarify that \(\varepsilon\) can be *any* positive number, so one really has a *family* of nested compact absorbing sets.  (This becomes useful later when discussing global attractors.)

With these additions the proof would satisfy both parts of Temam’s criterion and be airtight.

---

## 4.  Suggested amended conclusion
> Therefore, for every bounded initial datum \(A(0)\) there exists  
> \[
>   t^{*}(A(0),\varepsilon)=
>   \max\!\Bigl\{\ln\frac{M(0)-1}{\varepsilon},\;\ln\frac{|m(0)|}{\varepsilon}\Bigr\},
> \]
> such that \(A(t)\in\mathcal B_{\varepsilon}\) for all \(t\ge t^{*}\).  
> Since \(\mathcal B_{\varepsilon}\) is closed and bounded in \(\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\), it is compact; hence the discretised Asymptotic-Lenia flow is a **dissipative semiflow** in the sense of Temam.

(Everything else follows exactly as in your original note.)

---

### Bottom line
*The argument is essentially right but needs the housekeeping items above to reach publication-grade completeness.*
why didn't you put an abs sign on |M(0)-1|?

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Because in the \(M\)-estimate the quantity in front of the logarithm is *already known to be non-negative*:

\[
M(0)-1\;\ge\;0 .
\]

Here is the logic that makes the absolute–value unnecessary:

1. **What “big-\(M\)” measures**  
   \(M(t)=\max_{i,j}A[i,j](t)\) is the *largest* cell value.  Your initial data assumption  
   \[
   A[i,j](0)\in\mathcal B_{r}\subset[0-\varepsilon,1+r] \quad(r>\varepsilon)
   \]
   implies \(0\le M(0)\le 1+r\).

2. **Why we only care about the case \(M(0)>1\)**  
   If the very first state already satisfies \(M(0)\le 1+\varepsilon\) then the upper-bound
   component of the cube is satisfied from time \(t=0\) on, so that branch of the
   entrance-time estimate is *irrelevant*.  
   Only when \(M(0)>1+\varepsilon\) do we need to let the differential
   inequality
   \[
     \dot M\;\le\;1-M
   \]
   “push’’ \(M\) down toward the strip \([\,0,1+\varepsilon\,]\).

3. **Consequent positivity**  
   In that interesting case the numerator of the logarithm is strictly positive:
   \[
     M(0)-1>0.
   \]
   Hence \(\ln\!\bigl(M(0)-1\bigr)\) is perfectly well defined and no \(|\cdot|\) is required.

4. **Contrast with \(m(0)\)**  
   The minimum \(m(0)=\min_{i,j}A[i,j](0)\) may well be *negative*, so
   \(m(0)\) itself can have either sign and we write
   \(\ln\bigl(|m(0)|/\varepsilon\bigr)\) to cover both possibilities.

If you want to make the formula symmetric you can certainly insert an absolute value and then stipulate that the corresponding term is omitted (or taken as \(0\)) whenever \(M(0)\le 1+\varepsilon\).  Mathematically it changes nothing; the shorter version just reflects the observation that the “upper” clock only has to start ticking when \(M(0)\) is actually above the target ceiling.

parts: you're wrong, B_r is [0-r,1+r]

Right — \(\mathcal B_r=[\,0-r,\;1+r\,]^{N^{2}}\).  
That fact actually **reinforces** the reason the absolute value is not needed in the upper-bound clock:

* The largest entry \(M(0)\) can lie anywhere in \([0-r,\,1+r]\).
* For the logarithm we only invoke the term
  \[
     \ln\!\Bigl(\tfrac{M(0)-1}{\varepsilon}\Bigr)
  \]
  **when \(M(0)>1+\varepsilon\).**  
  If \(M(0)\le 1+\varepsilon\) the orbit is already under the ceiling \(1+\varepsilon\) and that part of the entrance-time estimate is skipped (taken as 0).

So in every situation where the term is active we have \(M(0)-1>0\), and the argument of the logarithm is positive without an absolute value.  
If one wants a single compact formula that is always defined, a common trick is to write

\[
t^{*}_{\text{upper}}=\max\!\Bigl\{0,\; \ln\!\bigl(\tfrac{M(0)-1}{\varepsilon}\bigr)\Bigr\},
\]

which automatically drops out when \(M(0)\le 1+\varepsilon\).  Either way, no \(|\cdot|\) is required on that factor.

Is this a semiflow? Whats the shortest way to explain that

thoughts.content: The user is asking if the vector field F defines a semiflow. In considering a finite-dimensional ODE with continuous and bounded right-hand sides, the existence and uniqueness of solutions induce a 1-parameter semigroup, which satisfies semiflow properties. So, yes, it is a semiflow due to Carathéodory theory ensuring solutions exist in finite dimensions. The flow is forward in time but, in this case, due to the dissipative nature of the system, it is at least forward, with global existence influenced by exponential damping.

parts:
### Yes – and here is the “one‐paragraph” justification

Put the state vector  
\(A(t)=\bigl(A[1,1](t),\dots,A[N,N](t)\bigr)\in\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\)  
and rewrite the right-hand side in vector form

\[
F(A)\;=\;T\!\bigl(K*A\bigr)\;-\;A .
\]

---

#### 1.  \(F\) is **globally Lipschitz**

* The discrete convolution \(A\mapsto K*A\) is **linear**, hence Lipschitz with constant  
  \(\|K\|_{1}=\sum_{p,q}|K[p,q]|\).
* By hypothesis \(T\colon\mathbb R\to[0,1]\) is a smooth transfer (activation) function; on the compact set \([0,1]\) its derivative is bounded, so \(T\) is Lipschitz with some constant \(L_{T}\).
* Composition of Lipschitz maps is Lipschitz, and subtracting \(A\) just adds 1 to the constant.  
  Hence there is an \(L>0\) such that  
  \(\|F(A)-F(B)\|\le L\,\|A-B\|\) for **all** \(A,B\in\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\).

---

#### 2.  Picard–Lindelöf ⇒ global solutions

A globally Lipschitz vector field on a finite-dimensional space generates a **unique solution for every initial condition and for all forward times**.  Denote that solution by \(\Phi_t(A_0)\).

---

#### 3.  The semiflow properties

Uniqueness of the ODE immediately gives the semigroup axioms

\[
\Phi_{0}= \text{id},\qquad
\Phi_{t+s}(A_0)=\Phi_{t}\bigl(\Phi_{s}(A_0)\bigr),\qquad t,s\ge 0,
\]

and the dependence \((t,A_0)\mapsto\Phi_t(A_0)\) is continuous (in fact \(C^{1}\)).

---

### **Conclusion**

Because \(F\) is globally Lipschitz, the autonomous ODE

\[
\dot A(t)=F(A(t))
\]

defines a continuous semigroup \(\{\Phi_t\}_{t\ge 0}\) on \(\mathbb R^{N^{2}}\); that is precisely what Temam calls a **semiflow**.  (Since the vector field is also globally bounded, one can run the solutions backward as well, so in fact it is a full flow, but “semiflow” suffices for the dissipativity discussion.)
Is it sufficient to just write one sentence thats like "since Asymptotic Lenia is a flow, it is also a semiflow

Pretty much, yes:

> *Because the update rule generates a (full) **flow**—i.e. a continuous family \(\Phi_t\) defined for all \(t\in\mathbb R\) with \(\Phi_{t+s}=\Phi_t\!\circ\!\Phi_s\)—its restriction to non-negative times \(\{\Phi_t\}_{t\ge 0}\) automatically satisfies the two semiflow axioms (identity at \(t=0\) and the semigroup property). Hence Asymptotic Lenia is a semiflow.*

That single sentence is logically sufficient, provided the reader already accepts that your ODE is well-posed and defines a bona-fide flow.

A **flow** is a family \(\{\Phi_t\}_{t\in\mathbb R}\) that satisfies the semigroup axioms for *all* \(t\in\mathbb R\);  
a **semiflow** only requires them for \(t\ge 0\).  
Hence

\[
\text{flow}\;\Longrightarrow\;\text{semiflow}.
\]

So, yes—if you have already established (or cited) that the Asymptotic-Lenia ODE
\[
\dot A = T(K*A)-A
\]
generates a global flow, one sentence such as  

> “Because the system defines a (two-sided) flow, it automatically defines a semiflow in the sense of Temam”  

is logically sufficient.

*(If the reader might wonder **why** a flow exists, add a parenthetical clause: “—the vector field is globally Lipschitz, hence the ODE has a unique solution for all \(t\in\mathbb R\).”)*
what make something a flow. is it not enough to have an equation like \dot x = f(x) where f is continuous?

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
### “Flow’’ vs. “just an ODE”

| concept | minimal requirements | why a plain \( \dot x = f(x) \) with \(f\) merely **continuous** is *not* enough |
|---------|---------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **trajectory** | a single solution \(x(t)\) of the ODE on some interval | Existence and uniqueness may fail if \(f\) is only continuous (Peano / Osgood examples). |
| **semiflow** | a **family** of maps \(\Phi_t:\,X\to X\) defined for all \(t\ge 0\) such that  \(\Phi_0=\mathrm{id}\) and  \(\Phi_{t+s}=\Phi_t\!\circ\!\Phi_s\).  Continuity in \(t\) and in initial data is assumed (Temam). | To build \(\Phi_t\) you need **unique forward solutions for every initial state and for every \(t>0\)**.  Global existence is not automatic when \(f\) is merely continuous, and uniqueness can fail. |
| **flow** | same as semiflow but \(t\in\mathbb R\): solutions exist uniquely **both forward and backward** for all time. | Backward existence is even harder; finite-time blow-up or non-invertibility of \(\Phi_t\) prevents a full flow. |

---

#### What guarantees a (semi)flow for an autonomous ODE?

* **Local existence:** any continuous \(f\) gives it (Peano).
* **Uniqueness:** needs at least a *local* Lipschitz condition (Picard–Lindelöf).
* **Global existence for \(t\ge 0\):** need that solutions cannot blow up in finite time (e.g. \(f\) is globally Lipschitz or has suitable growth bounds).

If \(f\) is **globally Lipschitz on \(\mathbb R^{n}\)** then

1. Solutions exist and are unique for all \(t\in\mathbb R\).
2. The maps \(\Phi_t(x_0)=x(t;x_0)\) satisfy the group law and are continuous.

Hence the system generates a **flow** (and therefore a semiflow).

If \(f\) is only locally Lipschitz and you can prove “no finite-time blow-up forward,” you at least get a **semiflow**.

---

### Bottom line  
Writing down \( \dot x = f(x) \) with continuous \(f\) is *not* enough to claim you have a flow (or even a semiflow).  You must also have:

1. **Uniqueness** of solutions (usually via a Lipschitz condition), and  
2. **Global existence** in the desired time direction(s).

Once these are established, stating “the system defines a flow, hence a semiflow” is perfectly correct shorthand.
what if I have examples of unique solutions

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Having a **few concrete solutions that are unique** is a good check of your calculations, but it is **not sufficient evidence that the whole dynamical system defines a flow (or even a semiflow).**  You need a *uniform* existence–uniqueness theory that applies to **every** initial condition in the phase space and for **all** forward times (and for a two-sided flow, for all backward times as well).  

---

## Why isolated examples don’t establish a flow

| requirement for a semiflow | what isolated examples give you | what is still missing |
|----------------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------|
| **(i) Existence:**  for each \(x_0\in X\) and each \(t\ge 0\) there is a solution \(\Phi_t(x_0)\). | Only for the specific \(x_0\) you solved. | Need a proof (often a theorem) that *every* initial state produces a solution on \([0,\infty)\). |
| **(ii) Uniqueness:** different initial states give disjoint trajectories. | You’ve checked uniqueness for those special \(x_0\). | Must guarantee uniqueness uniformly—otherwise \(\Phi_t\) is not even well defined. |
| **(iii) Semigroup law:** \(\Phi_{t+s}(x)=\Phi_t(\Phi_s(x))\). | Holds automatically once (i)–(ii) are in place for all \(x\). | Without (i)–(ii) globally, the law fails outside the verified examples. |
| **(iv) Continuity in \((t,x)\).** | Verified at a few points at best. | Need continuity on \([0,\infty)\times X\). |

---

## What you *can* do with special explicit solutions

1. **Illustrate** behaviour (e.g. show boundedness, blow-up, etc.).
2. **Test** hypotheses (e.g. check if your Lyapunov function behaves as predicted).
3. **Provide initial seeds** for numerical experiments.

But they do **not** replace the general Picard–Lindelöf–type theorem (or any other global well-posedness argument) that upgrades the ODE
\[
\dot x = f(x)
\]
to a continuous semiflow \(\{\Phi_t\}_{t\ge 0}\).

---

## Quick checklist to turn an ODE into a semiflow

1. **Global existence**: show that every solution is defined for all \(t\ge 0\).  
   *Common route*: prove \(f\) is globally Lipschitz or derive a priori bounds that prevent finite-time blow-up.

2. **Uniqueness**: usually follows from a local or global Lipschitz condition.

3. **Continuity in initial data**: automatic if \(f\) is Lipschitz; otherwise prove separately.

Once you have these three items for *all* initial conditions, you can confidently write the one-liner:

> “Because the vector field \(f\) is globally Lipschitz, the ODE generates a (two-sided) flow—and therefore a semiflow—in the sense of Temam.”

With just a handful of explicit trajectories, you cannot.
why is the spacing around \forall always so weird? what's the standard why to handle it?

thoughts.content: The user seems to be asking about the unusual spacing around the universal quantifier `\forall` in LaTeX. It likely has to do with the positioning of `\forall` in math mode, specifically how it's spaced before/after or between variables. In LaTeX, `\forall` is classified as `\mathord`, like a letter, so it behaves differently from other operators. This can lead to the odd spacing they’ve observed. Let’s break down the math atom classes in LaTeX where `\forall` belongs to `\mathord` type.

In math writing, especially in LaTeX, the spacing around `\forall` can seem a bit off. Typically, something like `\forall x \in X` may have no extra space after the quantifier by default. Some authors use a thin space like `\,` to adjust the spacing, especially since TeX classifies `\forall` as a relation symbol, causing extra space between quantifiers and variables. If it looks too large, authors often customize it. The issue acknowledged by some users is that the default relation spacing can feel unexpectedly wide.

The user asked why the spacing around `\forall` seems weird. In LaTeX, `\forall` is defined as `\mathord`, which leads to tight spacing by default. Some users feel there’s too much space and want thin space after the quantifier (like `\forall x\, P(x)`), which is why recommendations like `\forall x\;` or `\forall x\,` exist. The confusion often arises because it behaves like a relational operator in some contexts, but the standard practice is to tighten it for clarity and consistency in math notation.

parts:
### Why it looks “off”

`\forall` (and its sibling `\exists`) are *ordinary* symbols in TeX’s eyes:

```tex
\mathord{∀}  % this is essentially how \forall is defined
```

Because both the quantifier **and** the variable that follows it are `\mathord`s, TeX inserts *no* space between them.  
In print that produces the perfectly tight

```
∀x
```

But to people who are used to reading prose it often *feels* as though something is missing, so the eye interprets the closeness as “weird”.

If, on the other hand, you ever see *too much* space it is usually because the quantifier has accidentally been promoted to the *relation* class—e.g. by typing a literal space after it, or by using a redefinition such as

```tex
\mathrel{\forall}
```

A `\mathrel` gets the same medium skip that “=” gets, which is clearly wrong here:

```
∀  x            % ← big relational skip
```

### How it is handled in professional copy

Most publishers follow either **ISO 80000-2** or **French Imprimerie Nationale** rules:

| after the quantifier | thin, fixed space (≈ 3 mu) |
| between stacked quantifiers | thin, fixed space |
| before a binary/relational symbol (∈, =, <, …) | default TeX spacing |
| inside parentheses | none |

That is the look you find in Springer LNCS, Cambridge journals, **Model Theory** by Chang & Keisler, etc.:

```
∀x∈X P(x)       % thin space after x, normal before ∈
∀x ∃y ψ(x,y)    % thin spaces between quantifiers
```

### The everyday LaTeX recipe

```tex
% put these in your preamble
\newcommand{\fa}[1]{\forall #1\,}
\newcommand{\ex}[1]{\exists #1\,}
```

and write

```tex
\fa{x\in X}P(x)            % ∀x∈X P(x)
\fa{x}\ex{y} \varphi(x,y)  % ∀x ∃y φ(x,y)
```

* `#1` is the *bound variable (plus any immediate condition)*;  
* the trailing `\,` is TeX’s predefined thin space (≈ 3 mu in the current math style).

That small, explicit space reproduces what you'd get from professional kerning without the risk of ever falling back to the too-wide relational skip.

---

#### Quick reference of useful spaces

| Command | Name | Width (textstyle) | Typical use after `\forall` |
|---------|------|-------------------|-----------------------------|
| `\,`    | thin | 3/18 em ≈ 0.167 em | **Yes** – most common |
| `\:`    | medium | 4/18 em | Sometimes used before big-gons like `∫` |
| `\;`    | thick | 5/18 em | Rare after quantifiers |
| `\!`    | negative thin | –3/18 em | Tighten things like `x!\!y` |

Use the thin one unless a house style guide tells you otherwise.

---

### TL;DR

*TeX is not confused — it’s faithfully doing what its math-class table tells it to do.*  
The universally accepted fix is to add a **thin space** right after the bound variable (or define a small helper macro that does it for you). That matches the spacing you see in professionally set mathematics and keeps quantifiers from looking either squeezed or adrift.

$\mathcal{B}_\epsilon=[0-\epsilon,1+\epsilon]^{N^2} \subset \mathbb{R}^{N^2}, \epsilon > 0$

should I use epsilon or varepsilon here?

Both `\epsilon` (ε) and `\varepsilon` (𝗲) denote the same Greek letter; the difference is purely the glyph.  
LaTeX’s default Computer Modern fonts give you two shapes:

| Macro | Result | Typical visual description |
|-------|--------|----------------------------|
| `\epsilon` | ε | “lunate”—looks like a small-cap Latin “c” |
| `\varepsilon` | 𝗲 | “curly”—two-loop form |

### What style guides and publishers do

| Discipline / series | House preference | Rationale |
|---------------------|------------------|-----------|
| Pure mathematics (AMS journals, Springer LNCS, CUP) | **`\varepsilon`** | More easily distinguished from “c”, “϶”, and set-membership ∈. |
| Analysis notes & textbooks (e.g. Rudin) | **`\varepsilon`** | Traditional “ε–δ” notation uses the curly shape. |
| Physics / electrical engineering | **`\epsilon`** for permittivity, **`\varepsilon`** or `\epsilon` for small positive numbers (depends on journal) | `\epsilon₀` is visually lighter with the lunate form. |
| Probability / statistics (error terms) | Mixed | Journals usually accept either if consistent. |

So for *“a small positive parameter”* (your case: the radius of a box), the mainstream mathematical convention is **`\varepsilon`**.

### Practical advice

1. **Pick one and stick to it throughout the paper.**  
2. If your document already uses ε for something semantic (e.g. dielectric constant), keep that as `\epsilon` and reserve `\varepsilon` for the generic “small quantity”, or vice-versa.
3. Declare shortcuts if you may need to swap later:

   ```tex
   \let\eps\varepsilon   % now \eps yields the curly form everywhere
   ```

   Changing to the other glyph is a one-line switch.

### Your specific line

```tex
\mathcal{B}_\varepsilon = [\,0-\varepsilon,\; 1+\varepsilon\,]^{N^2}\subset\mathbb{R}^{N^2},\qquad \varepsilon>0.
```

* I used `\varepsilon` to follow the prevailing math style.
* Added thin spaces and punctuation for readability; drop them if your house style differs.

---

**Rule of thumb:** in mathematical writing use the curly `\varepsilon` unless a journal’s template, your advisor, or a competing meaning forces the lunate `\epsilon`.

parts:
That ugly flat-top isn’t produced by TeX itself – it happens later, when the page (or the little snippet you compiled with *standalone*, **preview**, or `pdfcrop`) is trimmed too tightly.  
Ghostscript, which `pdfcrop` (and the *standalone* class in *crop* mode) relies on to compute the bounding box, sometimes “forgets” that superscripts drawn with blackboard–bold (and other AMS) fonts reach higher than a normal capital. The box it reports is therefore a couple of points too short, and the extra height of the `^{N^2}` is sawn off.

---

### Quick fixes

| Situation | What to do |
|-----------|------------|
| **You run `pdfcrop` by hand** | Tell it to keep a little white frame:  ```bash pdfcrop --hires --margin 2 file.pdf ```  (`--margin 2` leaves 2 bp on every side – increase if needed). |
| **You use the `standalone` class** | Give it a border option:  ```tex \documentclass[crop,border=2pt]{standalone} ``` |
| **You use the `preview` package** | Same idea:  ```tex \usepackage[active,tightpage,border=2pt]{preview} ```  (or set `\PreviewBorder=2pt`). |
| **Nothing is being cropped on purpose** | Then you have compressed the line spacing too much (`\linespread`, `\setstretch`, or `\baselineskip` tweaks). Raise it back up a bit:  ```tex \setstretch{1.05} % or whatever looks good ``` |

---

### A local patch if you can’t touch the cropping step

Add an invisible “strut” that sticks up just as high as your superscript, forcing the bounding box (and therefore `pdfcrop`) to include that extra height:

```tex
\newcommand{\bboxguard}{\rule[-1ex]{0pt}{3.3ex}} % adjust numbers if needed
...
$[0-\epsilon,1+\epsilon]^{N^{2}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{N^{2}}\bboxguard,\ \epsilon>0.$
```

Because the rule is zero-width it doesn’t change the typeset line at all, but it *is* seen by Ghostscript when the bounding box is computed.

---

### Why TeX lines don’t overlap in the PDF viewer

Inside the normal document TeX always keeps enough \baselineskip for the tallest item in the line, so nothing is really clipped – only the cropped *graphic* you later include suffers. That is why raising the line spacing cures the problem if you have squeezed it too far.

---

Pick the remedy that matches the way you generate your snippet; any of them will stop the superscript on \(\mathbb{R}^{N^{2}}\) from losing its head.
